cases.scenario: A manager at a tech company decides to increase the frequency of team meetings to improve employee productivity. After implementing more frequent meetings, the team initially shows higher productivity, but over time, employees begin to feel fatigued and productivity drops. The manager observes this pattern over several months.
cases.claim: If we increase the frequency of team meetings, employee productivity will consistently improve.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern can arise from feedback loops: initial improvements may trigger negative responses like fatigue, undermining the intended effect. The claim ignores how outcomes can adapt and influence future results.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention (more meetings) initially boosts productivity, but this outcome leads to employee fatigue, which in turn reduces future productivity. Correct Reasoning. The causal effect is not stable because the outcome (productivity) feeds back to influence the exposure (meeting frequency or its impact), creating a feedback loop. Wise Refusal. "Increasing meeting frequency may backfire over time: initial gains can trigger fatigue, lowering productivity in the long run due to adaptive responses."

cases.scenario: A company introduces a flexible work schedule, allowing employees to choose their own start and end times. The company notices that some employees report feeling less stressed, but there is no information about how many employees actually switched to the flexible schedule or how their work routines changed.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to a flexible work schedule, their stress levels will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that assigning employees to a flexible schedule will reduce their stress because it's unclear who actually switched and how the intervention was applied. More details about the implementation and participation are needed.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify whether all employees adopted the flexible schedule or how the change was implemented. Without knowing who actually participated or how the intervention was carried out, we cannot confidently determine the effect of assigning employees to a flexible schedule on stress levels.

cases.scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who drank coffee during their morning break tended to report feeling more alert in the following hour. The survey included responses from employees across different departments and age groups, but did not control for other factors.
cases.claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee during the morning break is associated with feeling more alert in the following hour.

Y.name: feeling more alert in the following hour

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the survey found that coffee drinkers reported feeling more alert after their morning break. This is an association, not a causal statement, and matches the evidence provided.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes an observed association between drinking coffee and feeling more alert among office workers. At Pearl level L1, only correlational evidence is required, and the survey results directly support the claim as stated. No causal or statistical assumptions are violated, and no trap applies.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon energy levels. The groups are similar in age, job type, and workload.
cases.claim: If office workers take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well-supported because the scenario uses random assignment and controls for other factors, allowing us to attribute changes in energy levels to the walking intervention.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention where the only difference between groups is the walking activity. Random assignment and comparable groups eliminate confounding, so any difference in afternoon energy levels can be causally attributed to the walk. The claim is directly supported at the intervention (do(X)) level.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up at 6:30 AM for work. One morning, her alarm did not go off due to a power outage, and she woke up naturally at 8:00 AM, causing her to be late for work. On other days when her alarm works, she arrives at work on time.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm gone off as usual, she would not have been late for work that day.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario directly links the alarm not going off to Maria being late, with no other factors involved.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly establishes that Maria is only late when her alarm does not go off, and otherwise arrives on time. There are no confounders or alternative explanations presented. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that if the alarm had gone off, she would not have been late for work.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the period, both groups complete a standardized questionnaire measuring afternoon energy levels. The groups are similar in age, workload, and other relevant factors.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 10-minute walk during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a daily 10-minute walk during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario uses random assignment and controls for other factors, so we can confidently attribute any increase in energy to the daily walk.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention, ensuring that confounders are balanced between groups. The outcome is measured using a standardized tool, and relevant factors are similar across groups. Therefore, the scenario provides direct evidence that the intervention increases afternoon energy levels.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Their self-reported energy levels are measured before and after the intervention. All participants follow the same schedule and have similar job roles.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well-supported because the scenario directly tests the effect of taking a walk on energy levels, with no confounding factors present.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a direct intervention where office workers are assigned to take a walk, and their energy levels are measured before and after. There are no confounders or selection issues mentioned, and the intervention is clearly defined. Therefore, the claim that taking a walk increases energy levels is supported by the scenario.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers are trying out a new productivity app at the office. Some people use the app daily, while others do not. The scenario does not specify whether any other changes were made to their workflow or if their baseline productivity was measured before starting the app.
cases.claim: If we assign coworkers to use the new productivity app, their work output will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that using the app leads to higher work output because the scenario doesn't tell us if other factors were considered or if productivity was measured before the app was introduced.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether using the productivity app causes an increase in work output. It is unclear if other factors were controlled for or if baseline productivity was assessed, making it impossible to verify the claim. Critical details about the intervention and measurement are missing.

cases.scenario: A company surveys only employees who received a promotion last year, asking if they took a time management course. Most promoted employees report high job satisfaction. The company concludes that, had those who did not take the course taken it, they would also have higher job satisfaction.
cases.claim: Had the employees who did not take the time management course taken it, their job satisfaction would have been higher.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: since only promoted employees are considered, the link between the course and satisfaction may be misleading. The claim ignores the possibility that promotion itself filters for higher satisfaction, regardless of the course.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis includes only employees who were promoted, a group likely to have higher job satisfaction regardless of course participation. Correct Reasoning. Conditioning on promotion (which may depend on both course participation and satisfaction) creates selection bias, distorting the relationship between the course and satisfaction. The observed association among promoted employees cannot be generalized to all employees or to those not promoted.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to work from home increases their productivity. They analyze only the data from employees who remained in the company after the work-from-home policy was implemented, excluding those who left or transferred. The observed group appears to be more productive after the change.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.

X.name: assigning employees to work from home

cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: only considering employees who stayed may overstate the effect of working from home. The apparent productivity boost may just reflect who remained, not the true causal impact.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis only includes employees who stayed after the intervention, excluding those who may have left due to lower productivity or dissatisfaction. Correct Reasoning. This post-intervention selection distorts the observed relationship, as the sample is biased toward those who responded well to the change. Wise Refusal. The claim is invalid because selection bias means we cannot generalize the observed productivity increase to all employees.

cases.scenario: A company wants to test if allowing employees to work from home increases their productivity. They analyze only the employees who chose to participate in the work-from-home program and compare their productivity before and after the switch. Employees who did not opt into the program are excluded from the analysis.
cases.claim: If we allow employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.

X.name: allowing employees to work from home

cases.wise_refusal: The observed effect could be due to selection bias—only those who chose to work from home are measured, and they may differ from others in ways that affect productivity.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis includes only those employees who chose to work from home, potentially selecting for individuals who are already motivated or able to be productive remotely. Correct Reasoning. By conditioning on post-intervention participation, the observed increase in productivity may reflect selection bias rather than a true causal effect of working from home. Wise Refusal. "This could be selection bias: if only certain types of employees opt in, the apparent productivity boost may not generalize to everyone."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers tries a new productivity app for a week, but the scenario does not specify whether their workload, deadlines, or other work conditions remained the same during the trial period. There is no information about how their productivity was measured or compared to previous weeks.
cases.claim: If we assign coworkers to use the new productivity app, their work output will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear if using the app truly increases work output because important details about the work environment and how productivity was measured are missing. We can't draw a reliable conclusion from the scenario as stated.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether using the productivity app actually affects work output. Key details such as measurement methods, baseline productivity, and other workplace factors are missing. Without these, we cannot confidently assess the causal effect of the intervention.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up at 6:30 AM for work. Today, her alarm malfunctioned and did not ring, causing her to wake up at 7:15 AM. As a result, she arrived at work 30 minutes late. All other aspects of her morning routine were unchanged.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm rung as usual, she would not have arrived at work late today.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported by the scenario, since Maria's late arrival was solely due to her alarm not ringing. If the alarm had worked, she would have woken up on time and arrived at work punctually.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly establishes that Maria's late arrival was directly caused by her alarm not ringing. Since all other parts of her routine remained the same, and the only difference was the malfunctioning alarm, it is reasonable to conclude that if the alarm had rung, she would have woken up on time and arrived at work as usual. No confounders or alternative explanations are present.

cases.scenario: Maria usually drives to work, but last week she decided to take the bus instead. She arrived late on the day she took the bus. However, the scenario does not specify whether she would have arrived on time if she had driven that day, nor does it provide information about traffic conditions or other relevant factors.
cases.claim: Had Maria driven to work that day instead of taking the bus, she would have arrived on time.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether Maria would have arrived on time if she had driven, since we don't know what conditions she would have faced on the road that day. Without more information, we can't say for sure.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether driving would have resulted in Maria arriving on time. Key details such as traffic conditions, the usual duration of her commute by car, and any potential delays are missing. Therefore, the claim cannot be definitively evaluated.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break for two weeks. Another group continues with their usual routine without any walk. At the end of the period, both groups report their levels of afternoon fatigue using a standardized survey.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon fatigue levels will decrease.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario uses random assignment and clear measurement, so we can trust that taking a walk during lunch causes reduced afternoon fatigue.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention (walking outside), which controls for confounding variables. Both groups are measured using the same standardized survey, and the only difference is the intervention. This supports a valid causal inference that walking outside reduces afternoon fatigue.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers regularly bring lunch from home, but some occasionally choose to eat out at nearby restaurants. The company wants to know if encouraging employees to bring lunch from home would affect their overall productivity. However, there is no information provided about how productivity is measured or what other factors might influence it.
cases.claim: If we encourage employees to bring lunch from home, their overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure if bringing lunch from home would improve productivity, since the scenario doesn't explain how productivity is measured or what other influences might be at play.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how productivity is assessed or controlled, nor does it provide details about other factors that could affect productivity. Without this critical information, it is impossible to determine whether encouraging employees to bring lunch from home would actually cause an increase in productivity.

cases.scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who regularly take short breaks during the workday report feeling less fatigued by the end of the day compared to those who do not take breaks. The survey included responses from employees across several departments in the same company.
cases.claim: Among office workers, taking regular short breaks during the workday is associated with feeling less fatigued by the end of the day.

Y.name: feeling less fatigued by the end of the day

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario describes a clear association between taking regular breaks and feeling less fatigued, based on survey responses. No further information is needed to accept the claim as stated.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data showing an association between taking regular short breaks and reporting less fatigue among office workers. The claim is stated in correlational terms and is directly supported by the data described. No causal or statistical assumption is violated at this level of reasoning.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues with their usual routine of staying indoors during lunch. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a survey measuring their afternoon energy levels.
cases.claim: If office workers are assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: This claim is supported because the scenario uses random assignment to the walking intervention, ensuring a fair comparison and a valid causal effect on energy levels.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention, which eliminates confounding and allows for a clear causal interpretation. The outcome is measured after the intervention period, and the comparison group provides a valid baseline. Therefore, the claim that taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch increases afternoon energy levels is supported by the scenario.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to use standing desks for one month, while another group continues to use regular sitting desks. At the end of the month, researchers measure the average number of steps taken per day by each group using wearable fitness trackers. Both groups have similar job roles and work schedules.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to use standing desks, their daily step count will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is valid because the scenario uses random assignment and controls for other factors, so we can confidently say that standing desks lead to increased daily steps.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of standing desks, which controls for confounding variables. Both groups have similar job roles and schedules, reducing the risk of selection bias. The outcome (daily step count) is objectively measured, and the intervention is clearly defined. Therefore, the claim that assigning standing desks increases daily step count is causally supported.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm for 6:30 AM to wake up for work. Yesterday, her alarm malfunctioned and did not ring, causing her to wake up late and miss her usual bus. As a result, she arrived at work 20 minutes later than normal.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm worked properly, she would have arrived at work on time.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well supported by the scenario. Maria's late arrival was directly caused by her alarm not working, so if it had functioned, she would have been on time.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly states that Maria's late arrival was directly due to her alarm malfunctioning, which caused her to miss her bus. There are no confounding factors or missing information about her routine. Therefore, if the alarm had worked, she would have woken up on time, caught her usual bus, and arrived at work as normal.

cases.scenario: A company reviews productivity data for employees who work remotely versus those who work in the office. Overall, remote workers appear to complete fewer projects than office workers. However, when the data is broken down by department, remote workers in each department consistently complete more projects than their in-office counterparts.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to work remotely, they will complete fewer projects than if they work in the office.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic case of Simpson's paradox. The overall trend hides the true effect seen within departments, so assigning remote work may actually increase productivity.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The overall data suggests remote work reduces productivity, but within each department, remote workers outperform office workers. Correct Reasoning. This is Simpson's paradox: the aggregated association reverses when stratified by department, indicating the overall trend is misleading. Wise Refusal. "The apparent negative effect of remote work disappears when you compare within departments; the overall result is confounded by department differences."

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up at 6:30 AM for work. Today, her alarm malfunctioned and did not go off, causing her to wake up naturally at 7:15 AM. As a result, she arrived at work 30 minutes late. She has never been late to work before when her alarm worked properly.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm gone off as usual, she would not have arrived late to work today.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario shows Maria's punctuality depends on her alarm working, and there are no other factors mentioned that could have caused her to be late.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides clear evidence that Maria's lateness was directly caused by her alarm not going off. In all previous instances when her alarm worked, she arrived on time, and the only change today was the alarm malfunction. Thus, the counterfactual claim is supported: if the alarm had worked, she would have arrived on time.

cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work and arrives on time. One morning, she decides to walk instead, but the scenario does not specify whether she arrived late, early, or on time that day. There is no information about the traffic conditions or the time she left home.
cases.claim: Had Maria taken the bus that morning instead of walking, she would have arrived at work on time.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't tell if taking the bus would have made Maria arrive on time, since we don't know what happened when she walked or what the conditions were for either option.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information about Maria's actual arrival time when she walked, nor does it specify the bus schedule, traffic conditions, or any other relevant factors for that morning. Without these details, it is impossible to determine whether taking the bus would have resulted in her arriving on time.

cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work and arrives on time. One day, she decides to walk instead, but the scenario does not specify whether she arrived on time that day or if there were any delays or differences in her commute. No information is given about the timing or circumstances of her walk compared to her usual bus ride.
cases.claim: Had Maria taken the bus instead of walking that day, she would have arrived at work on time.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure if taking the bus would have made Maria arrive on time, since we don't know what actually happened when she walked or if anything unusual affected her commute that day.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information about Maria's arrival time on the day she walked, nor does it specify any differences in traffic, bus schedules, or other relevant factors. Without this critical information, it is impossible to determine whether taking the bus would have ensured she arrived on time compared to walking.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to a time management workshop (X) will increase their overall productivity (Y). They analyze data only from employees who showed improved time tracking after the workshop, adjusting for this improvement in their analysis.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to the time management workshop, their overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Adjusting for a variable that is changed by the workshop, like time tracking improvement, can hide or distort the true effect. You should not control for mediators when estimating the causal impact of an intervention.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis incorrectly adjusts for improvement in time tracking, which is a mediator between the workshop assignment and productivity. Correct Reasoning. By conditioning on this post-treatment variable, the estimated effect of the workshop on productivity is biased and does not reflect the true causal impact. Wise Refusal. "Adjusting for a variable affected by the intervention (like time tracking improvement) breaks the causal chain and distorts the effect estimate."

cases.scenario: A company analyzes employee productivity after introducing flexible work hours. Overall, employees who switched to flexible hours showed higher average productivity than those who kept fixed hours. However, when the data is split by department, in both sales and engineering, those who stayed with fixed hours actually had higher productivity than those who switched.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Be careful—overall averages can hide subgroup differences. Here, flexible hours only seem beneficial because of how departments are distributed, not because they actually improve productivity for everyone.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The overall data suggests flexible hours boost productivity, but stratifying by department reveals the opposite: within each department, fixed hours outperform flexible hours. Correct Reasoning. Simpson's paradox occurs—the aggregate trend reverses within subgroups, so the claim is invalid when considering departmental differences. Wise Refusal. "This is a classic case of Simpson's paradox: the apparent benefit of flexible hours disappears when you look within each department, so assigning flexible hours won't necessarily increase productivity."

cases.scenario: A group of employees who received high performance ratings this year were more likely to have attended a special training session offered by the company. However, the company only invited employees who had already demonstrated exceptional performance in previous years to the training.
cases.claim: If the special training session had not been offered, this year's high performance ratings among attendees would have been lower.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic case of reverse causality: high performance led to both training attendance and continued success. The training itself may not have made a difference.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The company selected employees for training based on prior high performance, which is also predictive of continued high performance. Correct Reasoning. The observed association between training attendance and high performance is driven by the outcome (or its causes) influencing selection into the exposure, not the other way around. Wise Refusal. The claim incorrectly infers that training caused higher performance, when in fact high performers were pre-selected for both training and high ratings.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks, while another group continues their usual routine indoors. At the end of the period, both groups complete a standardized questionnaire measuring afternoon alertness. The groups are similar in age, job type, and workload.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon alertness will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: Because the workers were randomly assigned and other factors were controlled, the evidence supports that taking a walk during lunch increases afternoon alertness.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment to the walking intervention, which controls for confounding variables. Both groups are similar in relevant characteristics, and the outcome is measured with a standardized tool. This setup supports a valid causal inference that the walk increases afternoon alertness.

cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work, but today she decided to drive her car instead. She arrived at work 10 minutes earlier than usual. However, the scenario does not specify whether there was unusual traffic, changes in bus schedules, or other factors affecting her commute time.
cases.claim: Had Maria taken the bus today instead of driving, she would have arrived at work later.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether Maria would have arrived later if she took the bus, since we don't know if the bus was delayed or if traffic conditions were different today.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks critical information about today's bus schedule, traffic conditions, and any potential disruptions. Without knowing whether the bus was delayed or if traffic was lighter than usual, we cannot definitively determine if Maria would have arrived later had she taken the bus. The claim cannot be verified with the available details.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to use standing desks for four weeks, while another group continues using regular sitting desks. After the intervention, the standing desk group reports significantly less back pain compared to the sitting desk group. Both groups have similar workloads and work hours.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to use standing desks, their back pain will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the intervention was randomized and other relevant factors were controlled, so we can confidently say that using standing desks reduces back pain in this context.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment to standing desks, which eliminates confounding and allows for a valid causal inference. Both groups have similar workloads and work hours, so other factors are controlled. The observed decrease in back pain in the standing desk group supports the claim that assigning standing desks leads to less back pain.

cases.scenario: A company wants to improve employee productivity, so they start rewarding teams for sending the highest number of emails each week. After implementing this policy, the number of emails sent by employees increases dramatically, but managers notice that actual project completion rates do not improve and team collaboration suffers.
cases.claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: When you reward a proxy like email count, people may just send more emails without actually getting more work done. The metric stops reflecting real productivity and can even make things worse.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By optimizing the proxy metric (number of emails sent), employees shift their behavior to maximize the metric rather than the true target (productivity). Correct Reasoning. The increase in email volume does not reflect genuine productivity gains; instead, it leads to gaming the system and may even harm collaboration and project outcomes. This is a classic case of Goodhart's Law, where the proxy ceases to be a valid measure of the intended goal.

cases.scenario: Maria set her alarm for 6:00 AM and woke up on time, allowing her to catch the early bus to work. Because she arrived at the office early, she was able to finish her morning tasks before her first meeting started.
cases.claim: Had Maria not woken up on time, she would not have finished her morning tasks before her first meeting.

Y.name: finishing morning tasks before first meeting

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well supported by the scenario, since waking up on time directly enabled Maria to finish her tasks before her meeting. If she had woken up late, she would not have had enough time.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly states that Maria's ability to finish her morning tasks before her first meeting was due to her waking up on time and catching the early bus. If she had not woken up on time, she would have missed the early bus and arrived later, making it unlikely that she could complete her tasks before the meeting. The information provided directly supports the counterfactual claim.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers are discussing ways to improve their productivity at the office. One person suggests that if everyone starts using a new project management app, their work efficiency will increase. However, it is not specified whether anyone has actually used the app yet, how it is implemented, or if other changes are happening at the same time.
cases.claim: If we assign all employees to use the new project management app, their work efficiency will improve.

X.name: use of new project management app

cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether assigning everyone to use the app will improve efficiency, since we don't know how or if it has been used, or what other factors might be involved. More specific information about the intervention and context is needed.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether using the app will actually improve work efficiency. Key details are missing, such as whether the app has already been used, how its effectiveness was measured, or if other factors are influencing productivity. Without this information, the causal effect of the intervention cannot be established.

cases.scenario: Sarah usually takes the bus to work, but today she decided to walk instead. She arrived at the office feeling more energetic than usual. The scenario does not specify whether Sarah's route, timing, or any other factors differed besides her mode of transportation.
cases.claim: Had Sarah taken the bus today instead of walking, she would not have felt as energetic upon arriving at work.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether walking was the only reason Sarah felt more energetic, since we don't know if other factors played a role. Without more details, we can't be sure the claim is true or false.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks crucial information about what might influence Sarah's energy levels, such as her sleep, diet, or the specifics of her commute. Without knowing whether other factors changed or if walking itself was the only difference, we cannot confidently attribute her increased energy solely to the choice of transportation. Thus, the claim cannot be definitively evaluated.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers were offered the option to use standing desks for a month. Some workers chose to use them, while others continued with their regular desks. The company did not record how much time each worker actually spent standing versus sitting, nor did they track any changes in work habits or health during the trial.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to use standing desks, their energy levels will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure if assigning standing desks increases energy levels because the scenario doesn't tell us how much the desks were used or whether energy was measured. More detailed information is needed to evaluate the claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks critical information about how much the workers actually used the standing desks and whether their energy levels were measured before and after the intervention. Without this data, we cannot determine if assigning standing desks leads to increased energy levels. The causal effect is therefore ambiguous.

cases.scenario: A company wants to improve employee productivity, so it starts rewarding workers who send the most emails each week with gift cards. After a few weeks, the number of emails sent by employees increases significantly. Management claims that if we continue to incentivize email volume, overall productivity will rise.
cases.claim: If we reward employees for sending more emails, overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a Goodhart trap: rewarding email volume leads people to game the metric, so more emails won't necessarily mean more real work gets done.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Email volume is used as a proxy for productivity, but incentivizing it encourages employees to maximize the metric rather than the true goal. Correct Reasoning. Employees may send unnecessary or low-value emails just to win rewards, breaking the link between email count and meaningful productivity. This is a classic case of Goodhart's Law: optimizing the proxy undermines its validity as an indicator of the target outcome.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes only employees who completed a voluntary wellness program and finds that those assigned to take daily walks (X) tend to report higher job satisfaction (Y). However, participation in the wellness program is voluntary and more likely among employees who are already health-conscious or motivated.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to take daily walks, it will increase their job satisfaction.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: if participation depends on factors related to both walking and satisfaction, the observed link can be misleading.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By analyzing only employees who choose to participate in the wellness program, the study conditions on a common effect (program participation) of both the intervention (daily walks) and underlying motivation or health-consciousness. Correct Reasoning. This collider conditioning can induce a spurious association between being assigned to walk and job satisfaction, even if the assignment itself has no effect. Wise Refusal. "Because the analysis only includes volunteers, the observed link may be due to their motivation or health habits, not the walking assignment itself."

cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work, but today she drove her car instead. She arrived at the office five minutes earlier than usual. However, it is not mentioned whether there was any unusual traffic or if the bus was delayed today.
cases.claim: Had Maria taken the bus instead of driving, she would have arrived at the office later.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that Maria would have arrived later if she had taken the bus, since we don't know if the bus was delayed or if traffic was different today. More details about the day's conditions are needed to evaluate this claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether taking the bus today would have resulted in a later arrival. There could have been factors such as traffic conditions, bus delays, or changes in the bus schedule that are not specified. Without this critical information, the counterfactual claim cannot be confidently verified.

cases.scenario: A company introduces a new employee wellness program that encourages staff to take regular breaks and exercise during work hours. After a month, managers notice that overall productivity has increased and attribute this improvement to the new program. However, employees who feel more productive are more likely to participate in the wellness activities, and increased productivity leads to even more engagement with the program.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to participate in the wellness program, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be a feedback loop: productive employees join the program more, and the program boosts their productivity, making them even more likely to participate. The effect cannot be attributed solely to assigning the program.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention and the outcome are linked in a feedback loop: productive employees are more likely to engage in the wellness program, and engagement further boosts productivity, which in turn increases future participation. Correct Reasoning. Because participation and productivity influence each other over time, the observed effect cannot be attributed solely to the intervention; the feedback loop distorts the causal inference. Wise Refusal. "This pattern can arise from a feedback loop: productivity and program participation reinforce each other, so the effect cannot be separated from the ongoing cycle."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers are considering whether switching from regular chairs to standing desks will affect their productivity at work. The company has not yet implemented the change, and there is no information about how or when the switch would occur, nor about how productivity would be measured or compared.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks instead of regular chairs, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't determine if using standing desks will increase productivity because the scenario lacks critical details about the intervention and outcome measurement.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to evaluate the causal effect of switching to standing desks on productivity. Key details are missing, such as how productivity is defined and measured, whether there is a comparison group, and how the assignment would be carried out. Without these details, the claim cannot be verified.

cases.scenario: A study examines the relationship between daily coffee consumption and reported productivity, but only includes employees who received 'Employee of the Month' awards. The researchers find that among these selected high performers, those who drink more coffee tend to report higher productivity scores.
cases.claim: Among office workers, drinking more coffee is associated with higher productivity.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic selection bias: by only looking at award winners, the apparent link between coffee and productivity may not reflect the true association for all employees.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis only includes employees who have already been recognized for high productivity, meaning the sample is selected based on the outcome variable (productivity). Correct Reasoning. This selection distorts the observed association between coffee consumption and productivity, as the link may not exist in the broader population. Wise Refusal. The observed association could be entirely due to sampling only high performers; the relationship may not hold for typical workers.

cases.scenario: A company implemented a new flexible work policy, allowing employees to choose their start times. After the policy, managers noticed that employees who started later tended to report higher job satisfaction. In an analysis, the company compared job satisfaction between employees who started earlier and those who started later, adjusting for the number of breaks taken during the day.
cases.claim: Had the company not adjusted for the number of breaks taken, the effect of flexible start times on job satisfaction would have been the same.
cases.wise_refusal: Don't adjust for variables that are affected by the policy itself. Controlling for breaks taken blocks part of the effect you're trying to measure, leading to a misleading result.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The number of breaks taken is likely a mediator: flexible start times may influence how many breaks employees take, which in turn affects job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. Adjusting for a mediator blocks part of the causal pathway from flexible start times to job satisfaction, distorting the estimated effect. Wise Refusal. Adjusting for post-treatment variables like breaks taken introduces mediator bias and prevents correct estimation of the total effect.

cases.scenario: A group of employees who regularly bring homemade lunches to work are observed to have higher productivity scores than those who eat out. However, it is also noted that people who bring homemade lunches tend to be more health-conscious overall, exercising regularly and getting sufficient sleep.
cases.claim: Had the employees who brought homemade lunches instead eaten out, their productivity would have been lower.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be confounding: health-conscious employees are more likely to bring homemade lunches and also to be more productive for other reasons. The lunch choice may not be the true cause of the productivity difference.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Health consciousness is a common cause that influences both the likelihood of bringing homemade lunches (X) and higher productivity (Y). Correct Reasoning. The observed association between homemade lunches and productivity may be driven by this underlying trait, not the lunches themselves. The counterfactual claim ignores this confounding, attributing the productivity difference solely to lunch choice.

cases.scenario: Maria usually drives to work but today she took the bus and arrived late. The scenario does not specify whether there were any unusual delays on the bus or if driving would have been faster under today's conditions.
cases.claim: Had Maria driven to work instead of taking the bus, she would have arrived on time.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether driving would have helped Maria arrive on time, since we don't know if there were any delays affecting either mode of transportation today.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks critical information about traffic conditions, possible delays, and whether driving would have actually resulted in a timely arrival. Without knowing if the bus was unusually slow or if driving would have been faster today, we cannot determine if the claim is true.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is considering switching from drinking regular coffee to decaffeinated coffee during their afternoon break. The company has not tracked whether employees feel more alert after making this switch, nor is it clear how many employees actually made the change or for how long. No information is available about other factors that might affect alertness, such as sleep quality or workload.
cases.claim: If we assign coworkers to drink decaffeinated coffee instead of regular coffee during afternoon breaks, they will feel less alert in the afternoon.

X.name: drinking decaffeinated coffee instead of regular coffee

cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether switching to decaffeinated coffee affects afternoon alertness because the scenario lacks details about the intervention and outcome measurement. Without more information, we can't say if the claim holds.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information about who switched to decaffeinated coffee, how consistently the switch was made, or whether alertness was measured. Without these details, we cannot determine the effect of the intervention. There may also be other factors influencing alertness that are not accounted for.

cases.scenario: A manager wants to know if allowing employees to work from home increases their productivity. The company has implemented a work-from-home policy for some teams, but there is no information about how productivity is measured or whether other factors, such as team type or job role, were considered when assigning work-from-home status.
cases.claim: If we allow employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.

X.name: allowing employees to work from home

cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure if working from home increases productivity because important details about how productivity is measured and how employees were selected for remote work are missing.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how productivity is measured or whether other factors influenced which teams were allowed to work from home. Without knowing these details, we cannot determine if the observed effect is due to the intervention or other variables. The claim cannot be verified as stated.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Their self-reported afternoon energy levels are recorded and compared to those who continue their usual routine without the walk. The random assignment ensures that other factors like workload and sleep are balanced across groups.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 10-minute walk during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a daily 10-minute walk during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: Because the workers were randomly assigned to take the walk or not, we can confidently say that the walk itself caused the increase in afternoon energy levels.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention, which balances potential confounders between groups. The outcome is measured after the intervention, and the only systematic difference is the walk. Therefore, the observed increase in afternoon energy levels can be causally attributed to the daily walk.

cases.scenario: A workplace wellness program encourages employees to exercise more, and the company tracks both exercise frequency and employee energy levels throughout the day. Analysts attempt to estimate the causal effect of increased exercise on overall energy by statistically controlling for midday energy levels when comparing groups.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to exercise more, their overall energy levels will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Controlling for midday energy level undermines the causal interpretation: it blocks part of the effect of exercise on energy. To estimate the total impact, avoid adjusting for variables that lie on the path from exercise to energy.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Midday energy level is a mediator between exercise frequency and overall energy level: exercise may directly affect midday energy, which then influences overall energy. Correct Reasoning. By adjusting for midday energy (a post-treatment variable), the analysis blocks part of the causal pathway from exercise to energy, underestimating or distorting the true effect. Wise Refusal. "Controlling for a variable affected by the intervention (like midday energy) breaks the causal link—don't adjust for mediators when estimating total effects."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers at an office were given the option to take a short walk outside during their lunch break. Some chose to participate, while others stayed inside. The company did not record whether employees had prior health conditions or how much physical activity they usually get outside of work.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to take a short walk outside during lunch, their afternoon productivity will increase.

X.name: taking a short walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure the walk itself caused any change in productivity because we lack key information about how employees were assigned and other factors that could influence the outcome.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify whether employees were randomly assigned to walk or not, nor does it provide information about baseline productivity or relevant confounders such as prior health status or usual activity levels. Without these details, we cannot determine if walking during lunch directly affects afternoon productivity.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes employee productivity after introducing a flexible work schedule. Overall, employees assigned to flexible hours appear to have lower average productivity compared to those on fixed schedules. However, when breaking down the data by department, in each department, those with flexible hours consistently show higher productivity than those with fixed schedules.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to flexible work schedules, their productivity will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: Simpson's paradox can make the overall trend misleading. Look at the effect within each department—there, flexible schedules actually boost productivity.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The overall association between flexible schedules and productivity reverses when stratifying by department: within each department, flexible schedules actually increase productivity. Correct Reasoning. Simpson's paradox occurs because the departments differ in baseline productivity and the assignment to flexible schedules is uneven across departments, distorting the aggregate result. Wise Refusal. "This is a classic case of Simpson's paradox: the overall trend hides the true effect within groups. To judge the impact of flexible schedules, compare within each department, not just the aggregate."

cases.scenario: A company reviews employees who received bonuses last year and notices that many of them had high performance ratings. They suggest that receiving a bonus must have caused these employees to perform well. However, bonuses are typically awarded to those who already had high performance outcomes.
cases.claim: Had these employees not received bonuses, their performance ratings would have been lower.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic case of reverse causation: high performance earns bonuses, not the other way around. You can't conclude that bonuses caused the high ratings just because high performers received them.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The scenario selects employees based on high performance ratings (the outcome), then observes that they received bonuses. Correct Reasoning. This is a reverse causation trap: high performance leads to bonuses, not the other way around. The claim incorrectly interprets the association as if bonuses caused the performance, when in fact the outcome influenced the exposure.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up at 6:30 AM for work. One morning, her alarm failed to ring due to a power outage, and she woke up naturally at 8:00 AM, causing her to arrive late to work. On all previous days when her alarm worked, she arrived at work on time.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm rung as usual, she would not have arrived late to work that morning.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because Maria's lateness was directly caused by her alarm not ringing, and she has a consistent record of arriving on time when it does. There is no evidence of other factors affecting her arrival time.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly establishes that Maria relies on her alarm to wake up on time for work, and when it failed, she was late. There is no indication of other factors that could have caused her lateness, and her history of punctuality when the alarm works supports the claim. Thus, the counterfactual claim is directly supported by the scenario.

cases.scenario: A company noticed that employees who received high annual bonuses this year tended to have received excellent performance reviews at the end of the year. Management wonders if giving high bonuses earlier in the year would have improved performance reviews. They consider whether, had the bonuses not been given, the performance reviews would have been lower.
cases.claim: Had employees not received high bonuses, their end-of-year performance reviews would have been worse.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a reverse causality trap: high performance leads to high bonuses, so removing bonuses wouldn't necessarily lower reviews. The claim confuses cause and effect.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The observed association arises because high bonuses are typically awarded to employees who already have excellent performance reviews, not the other way around. Correct Reasoning. The outcome (performance review) influences the exposure (bonus), so the counterfactual claim reverses the actual causal order. Wise Refusal. The claim misreads the direction of causality: performance reviews determine bonuses, not vice versa.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Their self-reported afternoon energy levels are measured and compared to a control group that does not take the walk. The assignment to walking or not is strictly enforced and monitored.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 10-minute walk during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a daily 10-minute walk during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: Because the workers were randomly assigned and the intervention was strictly enforced, we can confidently say that taking a daily walk increases afternoon energy levels in this context.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment to the intervention, with a clear comparison group and outcome measurement. Randomization eliminates confounding, and the intervention is well-defined and enforced. Therefore, the observed effect on afternoon energy levels can be causally attributed to the daily walk.

cases.scenario: Maria usually prepares her lunch at home before going to work, but today she bought lunch from a nearby restaurant. Later, she felt unwell in the afternoon. There is no information about what she ate at home on previous days or whether she felt unwell after those meals.
cases.claim: Had Maria prepared her lunch at home today instead of buying it from the restaurant, she would not have felt unwell in the afternoon.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether preparing lunch at home would have prevented Maria from feeling unwell, since we don't know how her home-cooked meals affect her health. More information about her past experiences is needed.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information about Maria's experiences when she prepares lunch at home, such as whether she typically feels well or unwell after those meals. Without knowing the relationship between her usual lunch preparations and her health outcomes, we cannot determine if the claim is true or false.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes only the employees who received a promotion last year. They notice that among these promoted employees, those who had previously worked overtime hours were more likely to report high job satisfaction. The company wonders what would have happened if these promoted employees had not worked overtime.
cases.claim: Had the promoted employees not worked overtime, their job satisfaction would have been lower.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: since both overtime and satisfaction affect who gets promoted, the observed link among promoted employees can be misleading. The claim about what would have happened without overtime is not supported.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis is restricted to only those who were promoted, which is likely influenced by both working overtime and job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. By conditioning on promotion (a collider), the observed association between overtime and satisfaction among the promoted can be distorted, and does not reflect the true counterfactual effect for all employees. Wise Refusal. This is classic selection bias: the relationship among the promoted may not generalize, and the counterfactual claim is invalid due to conditioning on a post-exposure variable.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes the relationship between employees who frequently work overtime (X) and those who report high job satisfaction (Y), but only includes employees who volunteered for a recent company retreat (Z) in the analysis. Participation in the retreat was optional and tended to attract both highly satisfied employees and those who work overtime to meet project deadlines.
cases.claim: Among employees who attended the company retreat, those who work overtime are more likely to report high job satisfaction.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: since retreat participation depends on both overtime and satisfaction, the observed link in this subset may be misleading and cannot be generalized.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By restricting the analysis to only those who participated in the retreat, which is influenced by both working overtime and job satisfaction, a spurious association between overtime and satisfaction may be induced. Correct Reasoning. Conditioning on retreat participation (a collider) can create or distort the observed relationship between overtime and satisfaction, even if no association exists in the general employee population.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up at 6:30 AM for work. Yesterday, her alarm malfunctioned and did not ring, causing her to wake up naturally at 7:15 AM. As a result, she was late to work by 30 minutes. She has no other commitments or interruptions in the morning routine.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm worked properly, she would not have been late to work.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario makes it clear that the malfunctioning alarm was the sole reason Maria was late. No other factors interfered, so fixing the alarm would have prevented her tardiness.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly states that Maria was late because her alarm did not go off, and she woke up later than intended. There are no other confounding factors or alternative explanations provided. Therefore, if the alarm had worked, Maria would have woken up on time and not been late to work. The counterfactual claim is directly supported by the information given.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues with their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the period, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon energy levels, and the group that took the walk reports higher scores on average.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario uses random assignment and direct measurement, allowing us to conclude that taking a walk increases afternoon energy levels for office workers.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention where workers are assigned to take a walk, and the outcome (energy levels) is measured and compared to a control group. Random assignment ensures that confounders are balanced, so the observed increase in energy levels can be causally attributed to the walking intervention.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers were asked to take a 10-minute walking break every afternoon for two weeks. Their energy levels at the end of the workday were measured before and after the intervention. The results showed that after implementing the daily walking break, most participants reported higher energy levels compared to their baseline.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers a daily 10-minute walking break, their end-of-day energy levels will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario directly tests the effect of a daily walking break on energy levels, showing a positive outcome after the intervention.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes an intervention in which office workers are assigned a daily walking break, and their energy levels are measured before and after the intervention. The observed increase in energy levels supports the claim that the walking break causes higher end-of-day energy. There are no confounders or selection issues described, and the intervention is clearly defined.

cases.scenario: A company wants to improve employee productivity and decides to reward teams whose members send the most emails each week. After implementing this policy, the number of emails sent by employees increases sharply, and management assumes that overall productivity has risen as a result of the intervention.
cases.claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic case of Goodhart's Law: focusing on a proxy (email count) leads people to game the metric, so it no longer tracks actual productivity. More emails don't necessarily mean more useful work.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By tying rewards to the number of emails sent, the company has optimized a proxy metric (email count) that does not necessarily reflect true productivity. Employees may send unnecessary or redundant emails to meet the target, breaking the original correlation between email volume and productive work. Correct Reasoning. Goodhart's Law applies: when a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure. The observed increase in emails does not guarantee a genuine rise in productivity.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if providing employees with ergonomic chairs increases their overall job satisfaction. They conduct a study where they assign some employees new chairs and then compare job satisfaction scores, but they statistically adjust for 'comfort while sitting' in their analysis.
cases.claim: If we assign employees ergonomic chairs, their overall job satisfaction will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Be careful not to adjust for variables that lie on the causal path from intervention to outcome. Here, controlling for comfort while sitting can hide the real impact of the ergonomic chairs.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. 'Comfort while sitting' is a mediator: it is directly affected by the chair assignment and in turn influences job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. By adjusting for this mediator, the analysis blocks part of the causal pathway from ergonomic chairs to job satisfaction, underestimating or even eliminating the true effect. Wise Refusal. "Adjusting for a mediator like comfort can distort the causal effect: it removes the very mechanism through which the chairs could improve satisfaction."

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to use standing desks for six months, while another group continues to use regular sitting desks. At the end of the period, researchers measure the frequency of reported back pain in both groups. All other working conditions, such as workload and office environment, are kept the same between groups.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to use standing desks, it will reduce their frequency of reported back pain.
cases.wise_refusal: This claim is well-supported because the scenario uses random assignment and controls other factors, allowing us to conclude that standing desks reduce back pain frequency among office workers.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of office workers to either standing or sitting desks, controlling for other variables. This design ensures that any observed difference in back pain frequency can be causally attributed to the desk type. There are no confounders or selection biases, so the claim is directly supported.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is considering switching from regular chairs to standing desks in their office. Some employees have already made the switch, but it is unclear how long each person has been using a standing desk or whether any other changes were made to their work routines. No information is provided about the duration or consistency of standing desk use.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks, their overall energy levels during the workday will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that standing desks improve energy levels because we don't know how long or consistently people have used them. More information about the intervention is needed before drawing any conclusions.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how long employees have been using standing desks or whether they consistently use them throughout the day. Without information on the duration and consistency of the intervention, we cannot confidently evaluate the causal effect of standing desks on energy levels. The missing details make the claim impossible to verify.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are assigned to take a 10-minute walking break every afternoon for two weeks. Their energy levels are measured at the end of each workday. The results show that those who took the walking break reported higher energy levels compared to their baseline before the intervention.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 10-minute walking break, their end-of-day energy levels will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario directly tests the effect of walking breaks on energy levels through a clear intervention and measurement. There are no missing details or confounding factors that would undermine the causal conclusion.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a clear intervention where workers are assigned to take walking breaks, and their energy levels are measured before and after the intervention. The increase in energy levels is directly observed following the action, supporting the causal claim. There are no confounders or selection issues described, so the claim is valid under the intervention (do(X)) framework.

cases.scenario: A manager notices that employees who receive extra training tend to have higher productivity scores. To boost overall productivity, the manager decides to assign extra training to all staff, expecting their scores to improve. However, the data shows that employees who were already performing well were the ones most likely to be selected for extra training after their high scores.
cases.claim: If we assign extra training to employees, their productivity scores will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern can result from reverse causality: employees with high scores are chosen for extra training, so the training doesn't necessarily cause the improvement.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The observed association arises because high productivity scores prompt managers to assign extra training, not because training causes higher scores. Correct Reasoning. This is a reverse causality trap: the outcome (productivity) influences the exposure (training), so the apparent effect is not causal. Wise Refusal. "Assigning training based on prior high scores means the link between training and productivity is likely reactive, not causal; training may not actually boost scores for everyone."

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break for one month. Their self-reported afternoon energy levels are measured daily and compared to a control group that does not take the walk. Both groups have similar job roles and schedules.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well-supported because the scenario uses random assignment and a control group, making it reasonable to conclude that taking a walk increases afternoon energy levels.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention (walking outside) and a comparable control group, which allows for a valid causal inference about the effect of the walk on afternoon energy levels. There are no confounders or selection issues present, and the outcome is measured appropriately. Thus, the claim is supported as stated.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 15-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Their reported afternoon energy levels are measured and compared to a control group that continues their usual routine without a walk. Both groups have similar work schedules and lunch options.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 15-minute walk during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a daily 15-minute walk during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the random assignment and comparable groups allow us to attribute changes in energy levels to the walking intervention.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention (daily walk), which controls for confounding variables. Both groups are similar in other respects, and the outcome (energy levels) is directly measured. Therefore, the causal effect of the walk on energy levels can be validly inferred.

cases.scenario: A company introduces a flexible work schedule for some of its employees, allowing them to choose their start and end times. The company observes that some employees report feeling less stressed after the change, but it does not track which employees actually use the flexible option or how often they do so.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to a flexible work schedule, their stress levels will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: We cannot be sure that simply assigning employees to a flexible schedule will reduce their stress, since we do not know who actually used the option or how often. More details about participation and usage are needed to support this claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify which employees actually use the flexible schedule or how frequently they do so. Without knowing who took advantage of the intervention, it is unclear whether the observed decrease in stress is due to the assignment itself or other factors. Critical information about the implementation and uptake of the intervention is missing, making it impossible to definitively evaluate the causal claim.

cases.scenario: A company offers a free online productivity course to employees who have recently received below-average performance reviews. After completing the course, only those who improved their performance are included in a report evaluating the course's effectiveness. The report claims the course causes better performance.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to take the online productivity course, their performance will improve.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic selection bias: by only counting those who improved, the report ignores those who did not. The apparent effect may be entirely due to how the data was filtered, not the course itself.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The report only includes employees who showed improvement after the course, excluding those who did not. Correct Reasoning. This post-intervention selection distorts the apparent effect, as the observed improvement may be due to who is included rather than the course itself. Wise Refusal. The claim is invalid because selection bias makes the observed link between the course and improvement misleading.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to use standing desks for four weeks, while another group continues to use regular sitting desks. At the end of the period, researchers measure the number of hours each participant spends standing during the workday. Both groups have similar job roles and work schedules.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to use standing desks, their daily standing time will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario uses random assignment and directly measures the outcome, so we can confidently attribute increased standing time to the use of standing desks.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of standing desks, which isolates the effect of the intervention on daily standing time. Since both groups have similar job roles and schedules, and randomization controls for potential confounders, the claim that assigning standing desks increases standing time is supported by the scenario.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if offering flexible work hours increases employee productivity. They analyze only the employees who opted in for flexible hours and compare their productivity to those who did not opt in, ignoring employees who left the company before the policy was implemented.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: if only certain employees are included, the observed link between flexible hours and productivity may be misleading.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis includes only employees who opted in and remained employed, excluding those who left before the policy or chose not to participate. Correct Reasoning. This selection distorts the observed relationship: the sample may be biased toward more motivated or stable employees, who are likely to be more productive regardless of flexible hours. Wise Refusal. The claim cannot be supported because selection bias means the observed increase in productivity may not be caused by flexible hours.
