cases.scenario: A survey was conducted among people who use public transportation, asking if they listen to music during their commute. However, the survey does not specify whether it included only morning commuters, evening commuters, or both. The results show that many respondents reported feeling less stressed during their commute when they listened to music.
cases.claim: Listening to music during a commute is associated with lower stress levels among public transportation users.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be certain about the association because the survey's sampling details are missing. Without knowing which commuters were included, the results may not apply to all public transportation users.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario suggests a possible association between listening to music and lower stress levels, but it is unclear whether the survey included all relevant groups (morning and/or evening commuters). Without knowing the sampling frame, we cannot be sure the association holds for all public transportation users. The missing information makes it impossible to confidently evaluate the claim.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers are considering switching from regular chairs to standing desks in their office. Some employees have already made the switch, but there is no information on how long each person has been using a standing desk or whether other changes were made at the same time. The company wants to know if this intervention will affect energy levels during the workday.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks, their energy levels during the workday will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't say for sure whether standing desks will increase energy levels because important details, like how long they've been used and what else might have changed, are missing.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to evaluate the causal effect of standing desks on energy levels. Critical details such as the duration of standing desk use, possible concurrent changes, and baseline energy levels are missing. Without these, we cannot determine if the intervention itself leads to increased energy.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are considering switching from regular chairs to standing desks. Some employees have already made the switch, while others continue using their usual chairs. However, the scenario does not specify whether any other changes were made to their work environment, or if the workers were assigned randomly to each desk type.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to use standing desks, their overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that using standing desks will increase productivity, since the scenario leaves out important details about how the desks were assigned and whether other changes occurred. More information is needed to make a clear judgment.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether assigning standing desks leads to increased productivity. It is unclear if the assignment was random, if other factors changed simultaneously, or if productivity was measured in a comparable way for both groups. Without these details, we cannot confidently evaluate the causal effect.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon energy levels.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario uses random assignment, which allows us to attribute changes in energy levels to the walking intervention without bias from other factors.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention where one group is assigned to take a walk and the other is not, with afternoon energy levels measured for both groups. Random assignment eliminates confounding, and the outcome is directly measured after the intervention. Therefore, the claim about the causal effect of the walk on energy levels is supported.

cases.scenario: A manager notices that employees who take public transportation to work tend to arrive earlier than those who drive. The company considers encouraging everyone to use public transportation, believing this will make all employees arrive earlier. However, employees who live closer to the office are both more likely to use public transportation and to arrive earlier, regardless of their commute method.
cases.claim: If we assign all employees to use public transportation, they will arrive at work earlier.
cases.wise_refusal: Check whether distance from home is influencing both commute choice and arrival time. The apparent effect may just reflect that those living closer are more likely to use public transit and arrive earlier, not the mode of transport itself.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The observed association between public transportation use and earlier arrival is confounded by distance from home to office, which influences both commute choice and arrival time. Correct Reasoning. Without accounting for distance, the effect of assigning public transportation is distorted by this common cause, leading to a misleading conclusion about the intervention. Wise Refusal. 'This pattern could be due to people who live closer both using public transit and arriving earlier, not because public transit itself causes earlier arrival.'

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walking break every afternoon for two weeks. Their self-reported energy levels at the end of each workday are recorded and compared to a similar group who does not take walking breaks. The two groups are matched for age, workload, and baseline energy levels.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily afternoon walking break, their end-of-day energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a daily afternoon walking break

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario uses random assignment and controls for key confounders, allowing us to conclude that taking walking breaks increases end-of-day energy.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention where workers are assigned to take walking breaks, and relevant confounders such as age, workload, and baseline energy are controlled for. The outcome is measured directly and compared between groups. This supports a causal interpretation that the walking break increases energy levels.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break each day for two weeks. Another group continues with their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the period, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon alertness. The results show that the group who took the walk reports higher levels of afternoon alertness.
cases.claim: If office workers take a 10-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon alertness will increase.

X.name: taking a 10-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario uses random assignment and a clear comparison, so we can confidently say that taking a 10-minute walk during lunch increases afternoon alertness.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention, which controls for confounders and allows for a valid causal inference. The outcome was measured using a standardized survey, and the intervention group showed increased alertness compared to the control group. Therefore, the claim that taking a walk increases afternoon alertness is supported by the evidence.

cases.scenario: A workplace introduces a new flexible schedule policy, allowing employees to choose their start and end times. After the policy is implemented, management observes that employees who start work later tend to report higher job satisfaction. Based on this, they claim that assigning later start times will increase job satisfaction for all employees.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to later start times, their job satisfaction will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern could be due to reverse causation: employees who are already more satisfied may opt for later shifts. Assigning later start times won't necessarily make everyone happier.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Employees with higher job satisfaction may be more likely to choose later start times when given the option, creating a reverse causation pathway. Correct Reasoning. The observed association reflects that happier employees select later shifts, not that later shifts cause happiness. Wise Refusal. Assigning later start times to everyone may not improve job satisfaction, since the direction of causality is reversed.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers started using a new productivity app at work. After a month, some employees reported feeling more organized, but there is no information about how many people used the app, how consistently it was used, or whether other changes happened at work during that time.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use the new productivity app, their sense of organization will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure the app caused employees to feel more organized because we don't know how it was used or what else changed at work. More details are needed to judge the claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks critical details about the intervention, such as who used the app, how it was implemented, and whether other factors changed during the month. Without this information, we cannot determine if assigning the app would causally increase organization among employees.

cases.scenario: A group of employees at an office started using standing desks. The company noticed that some employees reported feeling more energetic during the day, but no information is provided about how long the desks were used or whether all employees participated. There is no mention of any comparison group or baseline measurements.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks, their energy levels during the workday will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that using standing desks will increase employees' energy levels because the scenario leaves out important details like who used the desks, for how long, and whether there was a comparison group. More information is needed to confidently support this claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether using standing desks actually causes increased energy levels. There is no detail about the duration of use, whether all employees participated, or if a comparison group was used. Without these critical pieces of information, the causal effect cannot be verified.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to either take a 15-minute walk outside during their lunch break or remain indoors. After two weeks, those who took the walk report higher levels of afternoon alertness compared to those who stayed inside. All other work conditions and schedules are kept constant across groups.
cases.claim: If office workers take a 15-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon alertness will increase.

X.name: taking a 15-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario uses random assignment and controls other factors, so the effect of walking outside on alertness can be confidently inferred.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention where workers are assigned to either take a walk or not, and all other conditions are controlled. This allows us to attribute the observed increase in afternoon alertness to the action of walking outside. The claim is directly supported by the scenario, with no confounding or other causal issues present.

cases.scenario: A company wants to assess whether assigning employees to a time management workshop (X) increases their overall productivity (Y). In their analysis, they adjust for the number of tasks completed immediately after the workshop, which is a direct result of attending the workshop. They compare productivity between those assigned and not assigned, controlling for this post-workshop task completion.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to the time management workshop, their overall productivity will increase.

Z.name: number of tasks completed immediately after workshop

cases.wise_refusal: Controlling for a variable affected by the workshop (like immediate task completion) can hide its real effect. To estimate the workshop's impact, don't adjust for outcomes that happen after the intervention.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis incorrectly adjusts for the number of tasks completed immediately after the workshop, which is a mediator between assignment and productivity. Correct Reasoning. Conditioning on this mediator blocks part of the causal pathway from workshop assignment to productivity, distorting the estimated effect. Wise Refusal. Adjusting for a post-treatment variable like immediate task completion can break the causal link and lead to misleading conclusions about the workshop's true impact.

cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work and arrives on time. One day, she decided to drive instead and was late. The scenario does not specify whether there was unusual traffic, road closures, or other factors affecting her drive that day.
cases.claim: Had Maria taken the bus instead of driving that day, she would have arrived at work on time.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that Maria would have arrived on time if she had taken the bus, since we don't know if the bus was running on schedule or faced its own delays that day.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks information about the conditions affecting both the bus and driving routes on that particular day. Without knowing if the bus was delayed or if driving was unusually slow, we cannot determine whether taking the bus would have guaranteed an on-time arrival.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm for 6:30 AM but today she forgot and woke up naturally at 7:15 AM. As a result, she missed her usual morning jog and had to rush to get ready for work. She arrived at the office ten minutes later than her usual time.
cases.claim: Had Maria set her alarm as usual, she would have arrived at the office on time.

Y.name: arriving at the office on time

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well-supported because the scenario directly links Maria's alarm-setting habit to her timely arrival at work. No additional factors interfere, so the reasoning is sound.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly describes that Maria's failure to set her alarm led to waking up late, missing her jog, and arriving late to work. If she had set her alarm as usual, she would have woken up earlier, followed her routine, and arrived at the office on time. There are no confounding variables or missing information in the scenario that would challenge this counterfactual claim.

cases.scenario: A company analyzed only employees who received annual performance bonuses and found that those who regularly attended optional training sessions were more likely to be promoted. They then asked whether, had these employees not attended the training sessions, their promotion rates would have been lower.
cases.claim: Had the bonus-receiving employees not attended the optional training sessions, their promotion rates would have been lower.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: since only bonus recipients are analyzed, the link between training and promotion may be distorted by how this group was chosen.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis is restricted to employees who received bonuses, a group likely selected for both high performance and motivation. Correct Reasoning. Conditioning on bonus recipients creates selection bias: both training attendance and promotions may be more common among this group, regardless of any causal effect of training. Wise Refusal. The observed association within this selected subset does not support the counterfactual claim for the same group, because selection distorts the relationship.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes only employees who received a promotion last year and finds that those who had taken a negotiation workshop were more likely to have received higher salary increases. The analysis excludes all employees who did not get promoted, regardless of whether they attended the workshop.
cases.claim: Had the negotiation workshop not been offered, the promoted employees would have received lower salary increases.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: by only looking at promoted employees, the link between the workshop and salary increases can be misleading. The effect may not generalize to all employees or reflect the true impact of the workshop.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis conditions on being promoted, a variable that may itself be influenced by both workshop attendance and other factors affecting salary increases. Correct Reasoning. By only examining promoted employees, the observed association between workshop attendance and salary increase is distorted by selection bias—those who are promoted may differ systematically in unmeasured ways. Wise Refusal. The observed effect among promoted employees cannot be causally attributed to the workshop without accounting for the selection process.

cases.scenario: Alex usually sets two alarms to wake up for work: one at 6:30 AM and a backup at 6:45 AM. Today, the 6:30 AM alarm failed to ring, but the 6:45 AM backup went off as scheduled, and Alex woke up on time. Alex's partner noticed the first alarm didn't go off but saw Alex up at the usual time.
cases.claim: Had the 6:30 AM alarm not failed, Alex would not have woken up on time.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a preemption trap: even if the first alarm fails, the backup alarm would still wake Alex up on time. The claim overstates the effect of the first alarm's failure.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Causal Structure. The scenario includes two potential causes for waking up on time: the 6:30 AM alarm and the backup 6:45 AM alarm. Preemption occurs because even if the first alarm fails, the backup alarm ensures Alex wakes up on time. Correct Reasoning. The claim incorrectly assumes that only the first alarm matters, ignoring that the backup alarm would have produced the outcome anyway. Thus, the failure of the first alarm is preempted by the backup.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes employee productivity after introducing flexible work hours. Overall, employees who switch to flexible hours show higher productivity than those who stick to fixed hours. However, when the data is broken down by department, every department shows that switching to flexible hours actually reduces productivity compared to staying with fixed hours.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern is a textbook example of Simpson's paradox: the overall trend reverses within each subgroup. Always check subgroup results before drawing causal conclusions from aggregate data.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Simpson's paradox is present: the aggregated data suggests a benefit from flexible hours, but stratifying by department reveals the opposite effect in every group. Correct Reasoning. The overall association is misleading because department acts as a confounder, reversing the direction of the effect when properly controlled. Wise Refusal. "The apparent benefit disappears when you look at each department separately; this is a classic case of Simpson's paradox."

cases.scenario: A survey was conducted among office workers about their coffee consumption and self-reported alertness during the workday. However, the survey does not specify whether the alertness ratings were collected before or after coffee consumption, nor does it indicate if participants consumed coffee on the day of the survey.
cases.claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee is associated with higher alertness during the workday.
cases.wise_refusal: We cannot be sure whether coffee drinking is associated with higher alertness because the survey does not clarify when the alertness was measured or if coffee was consumed that day. More details are needed to evaluate the claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks critical information about the timing of coffee consumption relative to the alertness ratings and whether coffee was actually consumed on the day of the survey. Without this information, it is impossible to determine if there is an association between coffee drinking and alertness among the surveyed office workers.

cases.scenario: A company introduces a new employee wellness program and tracks the number of sick days taken by staff. After noticing a reduction in sick days, management decides to further expand the program. Over time, employees adapt to the new system and begin reporting sick days differently, sometimes taking more days off when they feel the program allows it.
cases.claim: If we expand the wellness program, employees will consistently take fewer sick days.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern can arise from a feedback loop: as the program changes, employees adapt their behavior, so the effect of expansion may not be consistent over time.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention (expanding the wellness program) creates a feedback loop: employees' behavior adapts in response to the program, altering how they report or take sick days. Correct Reasoning. The initial reduction in sick days may prompt further expansion, but this change influences future employee responses, potentially increasing sick days or changing reporting patterns. The causal effect is confounded by this bidirectional feedback between policy and outcome.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walking break every afternoon for two weeks. Their productivity is measured using the number of completed tasks each day. The comparison group continues their usual routine without walking breaks.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 10-minute walking break, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well supported because the walking break was assigned randomly and productivity was measured objectively. There is no reason to doubt the causal effect in this scenario.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention, assigning workers to take walking breaks and measuring productivity against a control group. Randomization ensures that confounding variables are balanced between groups, supporting a valid causal inference. The data directly supports the claim that walking breaks increase productivity.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are observed during their lunch breaks. Some days, a few workers choose to take a walk outside during lunch, while other days they stay indoors. There is no information about the weather conditions, work schedules, or whether the walking is assigned or voluntary.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a walk during lunch breaks, their afternoon productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether assigning walks during lunch would actually boost productivity, since we don't know if walking was voluntary, what other factors were at play, or if the observed workers differ in important ways. More details are needed to evaluate this claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify whether the walking is assigned or voluntary, nor does it provide details about other factors that could influence productivity, such as weather, workload, or individual preferences. Without this critical information, we cannot determine if assigning walks would causally improve productivity.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is observed over a month. Some are given the option to use standing desks, but it is not recorded how many actually use them or for how long. No information is provided about their previous health status or work habits.
cases.claim: If we assign standing desks to office workers, their back pain will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that simply assigning standing desks will decrease back pain, since we don't know if or how the desks were actually used, or what the workers' initial conditions were.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify whether the workers actually used the standing desks or for how long, nor does it provide any baseline information about their back pain or other relevant habits. Without these critical details, we cannot determine if assigning standing desks will causally reduce back pain.

cases.scenario: A company implements a new flexible work schedule policy. Afterward, employees report higher job satisfaction, and the company observes that more employees participate in team-building activities. An analyst compares the actual world to a hypothetical world where the flexible schedule was not introduced, but assumes participation in team-building activities is fixed at its observed post-policy level in both worlds.
cases.claim: Had the company not introduced the flexible work schedule (while keeping team-building participation fixed), employee job satisfaction would have been lower.
cases.wise_refusal: Fixing a mediator like team-building participation breaks the causal chain. To assess the true effect, you must let mediators vary naturally with the exposure.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Participation in team-building activities is likely a mediator: the flexible work schedule may increase participation, which in turn boosts job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. By fixing team-building participation at its post-policy level in both worlds, the analysis blocks part of the causal pathway from the schedule policy to satisfaction, underestimating the true effect. This is a classic mediator-fixing error, violating proper counterfactual reasoning.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 15-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon alertness. The group that took the walk reports higher average alertness scores.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a 15-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon alertness will increase.

X.name: taking a 15-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is well-supported because the scenario uses random assignment and a clear comparison group, so we can confidently attribute the increase in alertness to the lunchtime walk.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention, which controls for confounding variables. The outcome is measured after the intervention period, and the comparison group did not receive the intervention. The observed increase in afternoon alertness in the intervention group supports the causal claim that taking a walk increases alertness.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes employees who attend both the annual innovation workshop and receive high performance reviews. They notice that those who work overtime are more likely to be in this group and also tend to receive more promotions. The analysis only includes employees who attended the workshop and got high reviews.
cases.claim: Among employees who attend the innovation workshop and receive high reviews, working overtime is associated with receiving more promotions.

Z.name: attendance at innovation workshop and high performance review

cases.wise_refusal: Conditioning on who is included (workshop attendees with high reviews) can artificially create an association between overtime and promotions. The observed link may not reflect the true relationship in the broader group.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By restricting the analysis to employees who both attend the workshop and receive high reviews (a common effect of overtime and promotions), the study conditions on a collider. Correct Reasoning. This selection can induce a spurious association between working overtime and receiving more promotions, even if no true association exists in the full employee population. Wise Refusal. "This could be selection bias: conditioning on workshop attendance and high reviews may create a misleading link between overtime and promotions."

cases.scenario: A company introduces a new flexible work schedule, allowing employees to choose their start and end times. Some employees adopt the new schedule, while others stick to the traditional hours. The company collects data on employee productivity over the next month but does not specify whether all departments or job roles were included in the analysis.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to a flexible work schedule, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether the observed productivity changes apply to all employees or just certain groups. Without more details about who was included in the analysis, we can't say for sure if assigning a flexible schedule will increase productivity for everyone.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not clarify whether the data covers all departments or job roles, which could influence the relationship between flexible scheduling and productivity. Without knowing if the analysis included all relevant groups or controlled for differences between them, we cannot confidently determine the effect of the intervention.

cases.scenario: A company implemented a policy where employees are assigned to use standing desks for one month. After the month, data shows that those assigned to standing desks reported less back pain compared to those who continued using regular desks. The assignment was random and all other working conditions remained unchanged.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks, it will reduce their reported back pain.
cases.wise_refusal: This claim is supported because the intervention was randomized and other factors were controlled, allowing us to conclude that standing desks reduce reported back pain.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment to standing desks, which eliminates confounding variables. The outcome, reported back pain, is measured after the intervention, and all other working conditions are held constant. Therefore, the observed reduction in back pain can be causally attributed to the use of standing desks.

cases.scenario: A company wants to improve employee productivity, so it starts rewarding teams based solely on the number of emails sent per week. After implementing this policy, the number of emails sent rises sharply, but actual project completion rates and meaningful collaboration do not improve.
cases.claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Boosting email numbers doesn't guarantee real productivity; people may just send unnecessary messages to hit targets. When you reward the metric, it stops reflecting what you care about.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By making email count the target metric, employees focus on maximizing emails rather than genuinely productive work. Correct Reasoning. This is a classic case of Goodhart's Law: optimizing the proxy (email volume) undermines its original correlation with true productivity. The increase in emails reflects gaming the metric, not meaningful gains in work output.

cases.scenario: A company introduces a flexible work-from-home policy and analyzes only the productivity of employees who voluntarily choose to work from home. The analysis finds that these employees are more productive than those in the office. The company concludes that assigning anyone to work from home will increase their productivity.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.

X.name: assigning employees to work from home

Z.name: voluntary choice to work from home

cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: the productivity boost may only apply to those who choose remote work, not to everyone if assigned. The observed effect is likely distorted by who is included in the analysis.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis only includes employees who voluntarily chose to work from home, likely those who are already suited for remote work or motivated. Correct Reasoning. This selection distorts the observed relationship: productivity may not increase for all employees if assigned, since the sample excludes those who would not choose remote work. Wise Refusal. "This is selection bias: the observed boost in productivity may reflect who opts in, not the effect of assigning everyone to work from home."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is observed during their lunch breaks. Some choose to eat outside in the park while others remain inside the office. The company wants to know if eating outside affects afternoon productivity, but there is no information on how productivity is measured or tracked.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to eat lunch outside, their afternoon productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't judge whether eating outside improves productivity because the scenario doesn't tell us how productivity is measured or what counts as an improvement.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how productivity is measured or what criteria are used to assess it. Without this critical information, it is impossible to determine whether eating outside causally affects productivity. The lack of outcome definition makes the claim unverifiable.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up at 6:30 am for work. One morning, her alarm did not go off, and she woke up at 7:15 am, causing her to be late. Had her alarm gone off as usual, she would have woken up on time and arrived at work punctually.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm gone off as usual, she would not have been late to work that morning.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario makes it clear that the alarm not going off was the sole reason for Maria's lateness. There are no other factors mentioned that could have affected the outcome.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario clearly establishes that Maria's lateness was directly caused by her alarm not going off, as she typically relies on it to wake up on time. There are no confounders or alternative explanations present. Therefore, the counterfactual claim that she would not have been late had her alarm gone off is fully supported by the information provided.

cases.scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who drink coffee in the morning are more likely to report feeling alert during the first few hours of work. The survey did not control for other factors, but the association between morning coffee drinking and feeling alert was observed across the group.
cases.claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee in the morning is associated with feeling alert during the first few hours of work.

Y.name: feeling alert during the first few hours of work

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario describes a clear association between morning coffee drinking and feeling alert, which is all that is required at this level.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data showing an association between morning coffee drinking and feeling alert among office workers. At Pearl level L1, only the presence of an association is required, and the scenario directly supports the claim as stated. No causal or statistical assumption is violated.

cases.scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who drank coffee during the workday were more likely to report feeling alert in the afternoon compared to those who did not drink coffee. The survey did not control for other factors such as sleep quality or workload.
cases.claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee during the workday is associated with feeling alert in the afternoon.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario directly reports an association between drinking coffee and feeling alert in the afternoon. No further information is needed to establish this association at the observational level.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data indicating an association between coffee consumption and afternoon alertness among office workers. At the L1 (Association) level, it is sufficient to state that drinking coffee is associated with feeling alert, regardless of possible confounders. The claim is supported as stated by the scenario.

cases.scenario: A company wants to improve employee productivity and decides to reward teams based on the number of emails sent each week. Teams quickly adapt by sending more emails, including unnecessary or redundant messages, just to meet the target. Management observes a sharp increase in email volume but notices no improvement in actual project completion or meaningful collaboration.
cases.claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic case of Goodhart's Law: once you reward email volume, people game the system and the metric no longer measures real productivity.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By tying rewards to email count, the company has optimized a proxy metric rather than the true target (productivity). Employees respond by gaming the metric—sending more emails without increasing meaningful work. Correct Reasoning. The correlation between email volume and productivity breaks down once the metric is directly targeted, illustrating Goodhart's Law: the proxy ceases to reflect the intended outcome.

cases.scenario: A survey is conducted among employees who have recently received a promotion at work, asking about their job satisfaction levels. The analysis finds that those who were promoted after working overtime report higher satisfaction than those promoted without overtime. The survey only includes employees who received a promotion in the past year.
cases.claim: Among employees, working overtime is associated with higher job satisfaction.
cases.wise_refusal: Because the survey only includes promoted employees, the apparent link between overtime and satisfaction may be misleading. Selection on promotion status can distort the true relationship.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The sample only includes employees who received a recent promotion, conditioning on an outcome-related variable. Correct Reasoning. By restricting analysis to promoted employees, we select a group where both overtime and satisfaction may be linked to promotion, distorting the association between overtime and satisfaction for all employees. Wise Refusal. "This could be selection bias: since only promoted employees are surveyed, the observed link between overtime and satisfaction may not reflect the true association for all employees."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers started using a new productivity app at work. Some reported feeling more organized after a week, but it is unclear how many actually used the app regularly or what other changes occurred in their workflow during this period.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use the new productivity app, their sense of organization will increase after one week.

Y.name: sense of organization after one week

cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether assigning the app actually led to increased organization, since we don't know if everyone used it or if other changes occurred at the same time. More details are needed to judge the claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify whether all employees used the app as assigned or if other factors influenced their sense of organization. Without knowing the level of compliance and what else changed in their work environment, we cannot determine the effect of assigning the app on organization. The claim cannot be verified with the information given.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up at 6:30 AM for work. One morning, her alarm malfunctioned and did not go off, causing her to wake up naturally at 7:15 AM. As a result, she arrived at work 30 minutes late. She has never been late on days when her alarm works.
cases.claim: Had Maria's alarm worked that morning, she would not have arrived late to work.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because Maria's lateness was directly caused by her alarm not working, and she is always on time when it works. There is no reason to doubt the counterfactual statement in this scenario.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides clear evidence that Maria's alarm malfunction directly led to her being late, and she has a consistent history of punctuality when her alarm works. There are no confounding factors or missing information that would undermine the counterfactual claim. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that, had her alarm worked, she would have arrived on time.

cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work, but last Friday she decided to walk instead. That day, she arrived at the office 10 minutes late. The scenario does not mention how long the bus ride typically takes or whether there were any unusual circumstances affecting either mode of transport.
cases.claim: Had Maria taken the bus instead of walking last Friday, she would have arrived at the office on time.

Y.name: arriving at the office on time

cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether Maria would have arrived on time if she had taken the bus, since we don't know how long the bus ride usually takes or if there were any delays that day.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks crucial information about the usual duration of Maria's bus ride, potential delays, and any factors that might have affected her commute that day. Without knowing how the bus compares to walking under those specific circumstances, we cannot determine whether taking the bus would have resulted in her arriving on time.

cases.scenario: A workplace wellness program is implemented, and researchers want to know if assigning employees to participate in regular group exercise sessions (X) increases their overall job satisfaction (Y). In the analysis, the researchers adjust for employees' post-intervention energy levels, which are measured after the exercise sessions.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to regular group exercise sessions, their overall job satisfaction will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: By controlling for energy levels that are themselves changed by exercise, the analysis removes part of the effect we're trying to measure. This adjustment makes the claim about exercise and job satisfaction unreliable.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis incorrectly adjusts for post-intervention energy level, which is a mediator between group exercise and job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. Conditioning on a mediator blocks part of the causal pathway from exercise to satisfaction, distorting the estimated effect and making the claim invalid. Wise Refusal. "Adjusting for a variable affected by the intervention (like post-exercise energy) breaks the causal chain and can hide or distort the true effect of group exercise on job satisfaction."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers decides to start taking short walks during their lunch break. Some people join the walks, but the scenario does not specify whether anyone else in the office changed their habits or if there were other changes in the workplace at the same time. No information is given about how long the walking routine lasted or whether other health initiatives were introduced.
cases.claim: If we assign coworkers to take short walks during lunch breaks, their overall energy levels in the afternoon will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that walking during lunch actually improves afternoon energy levels, because the scenario leaves out important details about what else might have changed and how outcomes were measured. More information is needed to judge the claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether the intervention of walking during lunch directly affects afternoon energy levels. Key details are missing, such as whether other factors changed at the same time, how energy levels were measured, or if there was a comparison group. Without this information, we cannot confidently assess the causal effect.

cases.scenario: A workplace wellness program encourages employees to participate in lunchtime yoga classes. Observational data shows that employees who attend yoga have lower stress levels compared to those who do not. However, employees who choose to attend yoga are often those who already practice other stress-reducing activities outside of work.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to attend lunchtime yoga classes, their stress levels will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be confounding: employees who choose yoga may already have lower stress due to their lifestyle. Without controlling for these habits, we can't attribute the stress reduction to yoga attendance alone.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Employees who attend yoga are likely to have personal interests and habits that already reduce stress, acting as confounders. Correct Reasoning. The observed association between yoga attendance and lower stress is confounded by these pre-existing characteristics, not solely by the yoga intervention itself. Wise Refusal. 'The apparent effect may be due to people who are already invested in stress management choosing yoga, not the yoga class itself.'

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers noticed that some people who bring homemade lunches to work seem to have more energy in the afternoons. Without these details, it is not possible to determine whether the observed association is valid or if other explanations exist.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 15-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring their overall mood and stress levels. The group that took daily walks reports significantly lower stress and improved mood compared to the group that did not walk.

cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized intervention where office workers are assigned to take daily walks, and their outcomes are directly measured and compared to a control group. Random assignment helps eliminate confounding variables, so the observed improvement in mood and stress can be causally attributed to the walking intervention. The claim is supported as stated under the intervention (do(X)) framework.

cases.scenario: A company reviews employee productivity data and notices that, overall, employees who attend more training sessions tend to have lower annual performance scores. However, when looking separately at junior and senior employees, attending more training is associated with higher performance scores in both groups. The overall negative association appears when the data are aggregated.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to attend more training sessions, their annual performance scores will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: Don't trust the overall trend without checking subgroups. The negative association is misleading—within each group, training helps performance.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Simpson's paradox occurs here: the overall data show a negative association between training and performance, but within both junior and senior subgroups, the association is positive. Correct Reasoning. Aggregating across groups with different baseline performance and training rates reverses the true effect seen within each group. Wise Refusal. "This is a classic Simpson's paradox case: the overall trend hides the positive effect of training within each subgroup. Assigning more training could actually improve performance, contrary to the aggregate data."

cases.scenario: A survey was conducted among office workers to see if those who drink coffee at work tend to report higher levels of alertness during the afternoon. The survey collected responses about coffee consumption and self-reported alertness, but did not ask about other habits or health conditions. The results showed that coffee drinkers reported higher afternoon alertness than non-coffee drinkers.

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported by the observed association in the survey. Based on the data, office workers who drink coffee tend to report higher afternoon alertness.

cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data showing a positive association between coffee consumption and afternoon alertness among office workers. Since the claim is about association and does not imply causation, the evidence directly supports it at the L1 (Association) level. No causal or statistical assumption is violated, and no trap applies.

cases.scenario: A survey is conducted among people who have recently quit their jobs to assess their levels of job satisfaction before leaving. The sample only includes individuals who have voluntarily resigned within the last month. Researchers find that most respondents report low job satisfaction prior to quitting.
cases.claim: Among all employees, low job satisfaction is strongly associated with quitting a job.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: surveying only those who quit means the observed association may not reflect the true relationship among all employees.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The survey only includes people who have already quit, so the sample is conditioned on the outcome (quitting). Correct Reasoning. This selection distorts the observed association between job satisfaction and quitting, as it excludes those who stayed despite low satisfaction or quit for other reasons. Wise Refusal. "This is selection bias: by only surveying quitters, the link between low satisfaction and quitting is exaggerated and cannot be generalized to all employees."

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues with their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the period, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon energy levels. Both groups are comparable in relevant characteristics, and the outcome is measured with a standardized survey. This supports a valid causal inference that taking a daily walk increases afternoon energy levels.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers starts using standing desks. After a few weeks, some report feeling less tired at the end of the day. However, there is no information about whether other factors like workload, break frequency, or prior health conditions were tracked.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to work from home will increase their overall productivity. cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work, but today she decided to walk instead. She arrived at her office feeling more energetic than usual. However, it is not specified whether she had a different breakfast, slept better, or changed any other part of her routine today.

cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear if walking was the only reason Maria felt more energetic, since other parts of her routine might have changed. Without more details, we can't say for sure what would have happened if she had taken the bus.

cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether walking was the sole reason Maria felt more energetic, as other factors like sleep or breakfast could have influenced her energy level. Without knowing if these other variables changed, we cannot confidently assess the counterfactual claim.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes only employees who participated in a voluntary wellness program and completed all required check-ins. They notice that among these compliant participants, those assigned to daily meditation sessions tend to report higher job satisfaction than those who were not assigned meditation. The analysis excludes employees who dropped out or missed check-ins.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to daily meditation sessions, it will increase their job satisfaction.
cases.wise_refusal: Because the analysis only includes compliant employees, the apparent effect of meditation on job satisfaction may be due to selection bias, not a true causal impact. The observed association could be entirely driven by who sticks with the program.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis only includes employees who complied with all check-ins, which is a common effect of both being assigned meditation and having higher job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. Conditioning on compliance (a collider) can induce a spurious association between assignment and satisfaction, even if the intervention has no real effect. Wise Refusal. "This pattern could be misleading: by analyzing only those who completed all check-ins, you may be seeing an association caused by selection bias, not by the meditation itself."

cases.scenario: Julia usually takes the bus to work every morning. Today, she arrived late to her office. The scenario does not specify whether there were any unusual delays or changes in her routine, nor does it mention the reasons for her lateness.
cases.claim: Had Julia not taken the bus this morning, she would have arrived at work on time.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that Julia would have arrived on time if she hadn't taken the bus, since we don't know what else might have affected her commute or what other options she had.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether taking the bus was the cause of Julia's lateness. There is no detail about traffic, bus delays, alternative transportation, or other factors that could have influenced her arrival time. cases.scenario: A survey is conducted among employees who have recently received promotions at a large company. The survey finds that those who attended leadership workshops are more likely to report high job satisfaction than those who did not. However, only employees who were promoted were invited to participate in the survey.

cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The sample only includes employees who were promoted, which is likely related to both attending workshops and job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. By conditioning on promotion status, the observed association between workshop attendance and job satisfaction may be distorted, as those not promoted (and possibly less satisfied) are excluded. Wise Refusal. "This could be selection bias: since only promoted employees are surveyed, the link between workshops and satisfaction may not reflect the true association for all employees."

cases.scenario: Maria usually brings her lunch from home, but today she bought lunch from a nearby cafe. She felt energetic during the afternoon. However, it is not mentioned whether she typically feels energetic or tired after eating her homemade lunches.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a standardized questionnaire measuring their self-reported energy levels in the afternoon.

The outcome is measured in both groups after the intervention period, and the comparison is direct. cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to use standing desks for three months, while another group continues using regular sitting desks. At the end of the period, both groups are surveyed about their reported back pain levels, and other factors like age and prior health conditions are balanced between groups.

cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario uses random assignment, which means any difference in back pain is likely due to the standing desks rather than other factors.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of standing desks, which controls for confounding variables and allows for a valid causal inference. Since other factors are balanced and the intervention is clearly defined, the observed difference in reported back pain can be attributed to the use of standing desks. This supports the claim at the intervention level.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to use standing desks for two months, while another group continues using regular sitting desks. At the end of the period, researchers measure the amount of back pain reported by each group and find that those using standing desks report less back pain on average.

cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment to standing desks, which eliminates confounding and allows for a valid causal inference. The outcome, reported back pain, is measured after the intervention, and the comparison between groups is direct. Therefore, the claim that assigning standing desks reduces back pain is supported by the scenario.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to a time management workshop (X) increases their overall productivity (Y). In their analysis, they control for the number of tasks completed during the workshop, which is a direct result of attending the workshop itself.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to the time management workshop, their overall productivity will increase.

Z.name: number of tasks completed during the workshop

cases.wise_refusal: Controlling for the number of tasks completed during the workshop is a mistake—it’s part of how the workshop improves productivity. This adjustment hides the true effect, so the claim isn’t valid as stated.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The number of tasks completed during the workshop is a mediator: it is affected by the intervention and itself affects the outcome. Correct Reasoning. Adjusting for this mediator blocks part of the causal pathway from attending the workshop to increased productivity, underestimating or even nullifying the true effect. Wise Refusal. "Controlling for a variable that is itself caused by the intervention breaks the causal chain—this adjustment can mask the actual impact of the workshop on productivity."

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Another group continues their usual routine without the walk. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon energy levels.

This design controls for confounders and allows us to attribute any observed difference in afternoon energy levels to the intervention. The claim is directly supported by the scenario and the causal effect can be validly inferred.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers were surveyed about their coffee drinking habits and their reported alertness levels during the workday. cases.scenario: Alex missed his morning bus due to waking up late, which caused him to arrive at work 30 minutes after his usual start time. On days when Alex catches the bus on time, he consistently arrives at work before 9 AM. Today, he arrived at 9:30 AM because he missed the bus.

It also specifies that when Alex catches the bus, he always arrives before 9 AM. Therefore, if Alex had not missed the bus, he would have arrived before 9 AM today. cases.scenario: A survey was conducted among office workers about their lunch habits. Some reported eating salads for lunch, while others did not specify what they ate. cases.scenario: A group of coworkers started using noise-cancelling headphones in the office last month. Some reported feeling more focused, but no information is provided about how their work performance was measured or compared to those not using the headphones.

cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario mentions coworkers using noise-cancelling headphones and feeling more focused, but does not specify how productivity was measured or whether there was a comparison group. Without details on measurement or controls, we cannot determine if assigning headphones would causally increase productivity.

cases.scenario: Maria usually takes the bus to work, but today she drove her car instead. She arrived at the office ten minutes earlier than usual. However, it is not specified whether there was unusual traffic, changes in bus schedules, or other factors affecting her commute time.

cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information about the conditions affecting commute times today, such as traffic patterns, bus delays, or route changes. Without knowing whether these factors were different from usual, we cannot confidently determine if taking the bus would have resulted in Maria arriving later. cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. The walking group reports significantly higher energy scores compared to the control group.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 10-minute walk at lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: taking a daily 10-minute walk at lunch

cases.wise_refusal: This claim is supported because the scenario uses random assignment and directly measures the effect of walking on energy levels, so we can confidently attribute the increase in energy to the intervention.

The outcome (energy levels) is measured after the intervention period, and a significant difference is observed. cases.scenario: A company introduces a new productivity tracking app for its employees. After noticing a drop in productivity, management decides to increase the frequency of app usage reminders. Employees, feeling micromanaged, start to find ways to avoid or ignore the app, which further decreases productivity over time.
cases.claim: If we increase the frequency of productivity app reminders, employee productivity will improve.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a feedback trap: increasing reminders can provoke resistance, causing productivity to drop instead of rise. Interventions that trigger adaptive responses may backfire, so the claim is invalid.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention (increasing reminders) triggers a feedback loop: employees adapt their behavior in response, leading to avoidance and lower productivity. Correct Reasoning. The causal effect is not unidirectional; the outcome (productivity) influences future actions (reminder policy), and employees' adaptive responses undermine the intended effect. Wise Refusal. "When interventions create a feedback loop, people may change their behavior in ways that counteract the intended outcome. Here, more reminders led to avoidance and decreased productivity, not improvement."

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm for 6:30 AM, which helps her wake up early and have enough time to prepare for work. One morning, she forgot to set her alarm and ended up waking up late, causing her to rush and skip breakfast before leaving for work.

Thus, the claim is supported by the scenario under the counterfactual reasoning required at Pearl level L3.

cases.scenario: A company introduces a new employee wellness program and tracks participation rates over several months. Management claims that increasing participation in the wellness program will continually improve employee health outcomes.
cases.claim: If we increase participation in the wellness program, employee health outcomes will keep improving.
cases.wise_refusal: Beware of feedback loops: as employees get healthier, their motivation to participate may drop, reducing future benefits. The effect is not simply additive over time.

cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention changes employee behavior, but as health improves, employees may reduce their engagement or the program's effect may diminish. Correct Reasoning. The causal link is distorted by a feedback loop: improved health can lead to less participation or complacency, which in turn affects future health outcomes. Wise Refusal. "This is a feedback trap: as outcomes improve, the response to the intervention may change, so simply increasing participation does not guarantee continued improvement."

cases.scenario: A workplace wellness program wants to measure the effect of assigning employees to a daily meditation session on their overall stress levels. In their analysis, they statistically control for the number of relaxation breaks employees take during the day, which is known to be influenced by the meditation assignment itself.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to daily meditation sessions, it will reduce their overall stress levels compared to not assigning meditation.
cases.wise_refusal: Controlling for relaxation breaks here is a mistake: it is part of how meditation reduces stress. Adjusting for it can make the effect of meditation look smaller or even misleading. To measure the true impact, don't control for variables that are downstream of the intervention.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The number of relaxation breaks is a mediator: it is affected by the meditation assignment and itself affects stress levels. Correct Reasoning. By adjusting for this mediator, the analysis blocks part of the causal pathway from meditation to stress reduction, distorting the true effect. Wise Refusal. "Controlling for a variable that is itself changed by the intervention (a mediator) can hide or even reverse the effect you're trying to measure."

cases.scenario: Maria usually drives to work and arrives on time. Last week, she took the bus instead, but the scenario does not specify whether she arrived late or on time. It is also unclear if there were any other changes in her routine or external factors affecting her commute that week.

cases.scenario: A group of students who regularly attend after-school tutoring sessions tend to score higher on their math tests. The observed association between tutoring and scores may be driven by motivation, not the tutoring itself. The counterfactual claim ignores this confounding, so we cannot conclude that tutoring attendance alone caused the higher scores.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to work from home (X) increases their productivity (Y). They analyze only the group of employees who complied with the work-from-home assignment and submitted productivity reports (Z).

By analyzing only employees who complied and submitted reports, the company is conditioning on a collider: compliance depends on both the assignment and potentially on productivity. Wise Refusal. "Because the analysis only includes compliant employees, the observed link between working from home and productivity may be distorted by selection bias, not the true causal effect."

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to work remotely increases their productivity. They analyze only those employees who voluntarily switched to remote work and remained in the program for at least six months, excluding those who left or returned to office work earlier.

cases.scenario: A survey of employees who recently received promotions shows that they tend to report working longer hours than those who did not get promoted. The data only includes responses from employees after the promotion decisions were announced.

The observed association may reflect that the outcome (promotion) led to increased working hours, not that longer hours caused promotion. cases.scenario: Maria usually sets two alarms for waking up in the morning. Today, she only set one alarm, and she overslept by 30 minutes. She had no interruptions during the night and her phone was fully charged.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm to wake up for work, but today she forgot to set it. As a result, she overslept and arrived late to her office. Her manager noted her tardiness, and Maria apologized, explaining the situation.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to use standing desks for six months, while another group continues using regular sitting desks. cases.scenario: A company analyzes employee productivity after implementing a flexible work schedule. Overall, employees who switched to flexible hours show higher average productivity compared to those who kept fixed schedules. However, when the data is broken down by department, in every department, employees on fixed schedules outperform those on flexible schedules.

cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic case of Simpson's paradox: the overall trend reverses when you look within departments. Assigning flexible schedules won't increase productivity if, in every department, the opposite is true.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The overall data suggests a positive effect of flexible schedules, but stratifying by department reveals a reversal: within every department, fixed schedules lead to higher productivity. Correct Reasoning. Simpson's paradox occurs because the departments differ in both schedule assignment rates and baseline productivity, causing the aggregate trend to misrepresent the true causal effect. Wise Refusal. "The overall boost in productivity is misleading—within each department, flexible schedules actually reduce productivity. Simpson's paradox can flip the apparent effect when group differences aren't accounted for."

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm for 6:30 AM to wake up for work. One morning, her alarm did not go off due to a power outage, and she woke up naturally at 7:15 AM, arriving late to work. On all previous days when her alarm worked, she arrived on time.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes only employees who volunteered for a new remote work program and completed a satisfaction survey. Both the likelihood of volunteering and reporting high satisfaction may be influenced by personal motivation. The company finds that those assigned to remote work report higher satisfaction than those assigned to in-office work, but only among survey completers.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to remote work, their job satisfaction will increase compared to in-office assignment.
cases.wise_refusal: Because the analysis only includes survey completers, the apparent effect may be distorted by who chose to participate. This selection can create a misleading link between remote work and satisfaction.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By analyzing only employees who completed the satisfaction survey, the company conditions on a variable (survey completion) that is affected by both the intervention (remote work assignment) and the outcome (job satisfaction). Correct Reasoning. This collider conditioning can induce a spurious association between remote work and satisfaction, even if no true causal effect exists. The observed difference may be due to selection bias rather than the intervention itself.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Randomization ensures that confounding variables are balanced between groups, so the effect of the walk on energy can be causally inferred. The claim is supported as stated by the scenario under the intervention (do(X)).

cases.scenario: A company wants to test if offering flexible work hours increases employee job satisfaction. In their analysis, they control for 'work-life balance' scores, which are measured after the flexible hours policy is implemented. The dataset includes employees assigned to flexible and standard schedules, along with their post-policy work-life balance and job satisfaction ratings.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their job satisfaction will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Controlling for post-treatment variables like work-life balance can break the causal link you want to measure. This adjustment hides part of the effect of flexible hours on job satisfaction.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. 'Work-life balance' is a mediator: it is affected by the flexible hours assignment and in turn influences job satisfaction. By controlling for this post-treatment variable, the analysis blocks part of the causal pathway from flexible hours to satisfaction, leading to a biased estimate of the true effect. Correct Reasoning. Adjusting for mediators distorts the causal inference, as it removes the indirect effect that flows through work-life balance.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. cases.scenario: A company wants to know if offering remote work increases employee productivity. They analyze only the productivity of employees who chose to participate in the remote work program, excluding those who declined or were not eligible. The observed data shows higher productivity among the remote workers.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to remote work, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: if only certain employees choose or are allowed to work remotely, their higher productivity may not be caused by remote work itself. The observed effect may not apply to everyone.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis only includes employees who opted into remote work, who may differ systematically from those who did not (e.g., more motivated or better equipped for remote tasks). Correct Reasoning. By conditioning on post-intervention selection, the observed increase in productivity may reflect characteristics of the selected group, not the effect of remote work itself. Wise Refusal. The claim is invalid because selection bias distorts the observed relationship; you cannot generalize from the selected subset to all employees.

cases.scenario: A company reviews employee satisfaction scores and finds that, overall, remote workers report lower satisfaction than in-office workers. However, when the data is split by department, remote workers in each department consistently report higher satisfaction than their in-office colleagues. The overall trend reverses within departmental subgroups.
cases.claim: Remote work is associated with lower employee satisfaction.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a case of Simpson's paradox: the overall trend hides the true relationship within subgroups. Always check subgroup patterns before drawing conclusions from aggregated data.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. When the data is aggregated across all departments, remote workers appear less satisfied, but within each department, the opposite is true: remote workers are more satisfied. Correct Reasoning. This is a classic example of Simpson's paradox, where the overall association is reversed within subgroups due to imbalanced group composition. The claim is invalid because it ignores the departmental breakdown, misleadingly suggesting a negative association.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to either take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break or remain indoors. After a week, their self-reported afternoon energy levels are measured and compared between the two groups.

cases.scenario: A group of employees who regularly work late hours at the office also tend to report higher levels of stress. Many of these employees have demanding roles that require frequent multitasking and quick decision-making. The company is considering whether changing work hours would reduce stress.

The counterfactual claim ignores that even without late hours, those in demanding roles may still experience high stress due to their responsibilities. cases.scenario: Maria usually sets her alarm for 6:30 AM on weekdays to get ready for work. Yesterday, she accidentally set her alarm for 7:00 AM instead and woke up later than usual. As a result, she missed her usual bus and had to take a later one, arriving at work 15 minutes late.
