cases.wise_refusal: Based on the information given, Maria's late arrival was directly caused by setting her alarm later than usual. If she had set it for 6:30 AM, she would have arrived on time.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides a clear causal chain: Maria's late alarm caused her to miss her usual bus, which directly led to her arriving at work late. There are no confounders or alternative explanations present in the scenario. Therefore, if she had set her alarm for 6:30 AM, she would have caught her usual bus and arrived on time.

cases.scenario: A company analyzes employee productivity after introducing a flexible work schedule. When looking at all departments combined, employees with flexible schedules appear to have lower overall productivity than those with fixed schedules. However, within each department, employees with flexible schedules actually show higher productivity than their fixed-schedule peers.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to flexible work schedules, their productivity will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern is a classic Simpson's paradox: the overall trend reverses within subgroups. You need to compare within departments to see the true effect of flexible schedules.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Simpson's paradox is present: the aggregated data suggest a negative effect of flexible schedules on productivity, but this reverses when analyzing within departments. Correct Reasoning. The overall trend is misleading because department differences confound the association; stratified analysis reveals the true causal effect. Wise Refusal. "This is a classic case of Simpson's paradox—department-level differences mask the real impact. Always check subgroup trends before drawing causal conclusions."

cases.scenario: A company introduces a policy where employees are rewarded for sending the highest number of emails per week, aiming to boost overall workplace productivity. After a month, the number of emails sent by employees has dramatically increased, but many of the emails are trivial or redundant, and actual project completion rates have not improved.
cases.claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, workplace productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic case of Goodhart's Law: when you reward a proxy, people game the metric instead of improving the real outcome. More emails don't necessarily mean more work gets done.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The company chose email volume as a proxy for productivity, but employees responded by maximizing the metric itself rather than the underlying goal. Correct Reasoning. Goodhart's Law applies: optimizing the proxy (email count) led to gaming behavior, breaking its correlation with true productivity. The intervention increased the measured metric, but not the intended outcome.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is considering switching from regular chairs to standing desks in their office. cases.scenario: Maria usually sets two alarms on her phone to wake up for work: one at 6:30 AM and a backup at 6:45 AM. One morning, the first alarm failed to go off due to a software glitch, but the second alarm rang as scheduled, and Maria woke up on time. She arrived at work without any delay.
cases.claim: Had the first alarm not failed, Maria would not have arrived at work on time.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a preemption case: the second alarm would have woken Maria up on time even if the first had not failed, so the claim overstates the effect of the first alarm's failure.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Causal Structure. Maria had a backup mechanism (the second alarm) that would ensure she woke up on time even if the first alarm failed. Correct Reasoning. The backup alarm preempted any effect the first alarm's failure might have had on her arrival time; thus, the outcome would have been the same regardless of the first alarm's status. Preemption Trap. The claim incorrectly attributes causality to the first alarm, ignoring that the second alarm would have produced the same outcome.

cases.scenario: Maria usually sets an alarm for 6:30 AM to wake up for work. Yesterday, she forgot to set her alarm and woke up naturally at 7:15 AM, which made her late for work. On all previous days when she set her alarm, she arrived at work on time.

cases.wise_refusal: Based on the information, it is reasonable to conclude that Maria would have arrived on time if she had set her alarm, since her lateness was directly caused by waking up late without it.

cases.gold_rationale: The scenario provides clear evidence that setting an alarm leads Maria to wake up early enough to arrive at work on time. The only difference on the day she was late was that she did not set her alarm, and all other days she was punctual when she did. This supports the counterfactual claim that, had she set her alarm, she would not have been late.

cases.scenario: A company wants to improve employee productivity, so they start rewarding workers based on the number of emails sent per day. Over time, employees begin sending more emails, but many of these are unnecessary or redundant, and actual project completion rates do not improve.
cases.claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This is Goodhart's Law in action: boosting email counts doesn't guarantee more real work gets done, since people may just send pointless messages to hit the target.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention targets a proxy metric (email volume) rather than the true outcome (productivity). Correct Reasoning. Employees respond by gaming the metric—sending more emails regardless of relevance—breaking the link between email volume and actual productivity. This is a classic case of Goodhart's Law: optimizing the proxy causes it to lose its value as an indicator of the desired outcome.

cases.scenario: A company introduces a new employee wellness program that encourages staff to take short breaks for stretching throughout the workday. Over several months, managers observe that employee productivity initially increases after the program starts, but then some teams begin to take longer and more frequent breaks, and overall productivity returns to previous levels.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to take regular stretching breaks, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern reflects a feedback loop: people change their habits in response to the intervention, which can neutralize the intended effect. The claim ignores how outcomes can influence future actions, so the expected improvement may not last.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention (stretching breaks) initially boosts productivity, but employees adapt by taking longer or more frequent breaks, which counteracts the intended effect. Correct Reasoning. This is a feedback loop: the action changes the outcome, but the outcome then alters future behavior, undermining the causal effect claimed. Wise Refusal. "When people adapt their behavior in response to a policy, the initial benefit can disappear over time. The effect is not simply 'do X, get Y'—the system responds and may erase the gain."

cases.scenario: A group of office workers is randomly assigned to take a 10-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks. Their reported afternoon energy levels are measured and compared to those who do not take the walk. All other aspects of their workday remain unchanged.

cases.scenario: A manager notices that employees who receive extra training tend to have higher performance reviews. Correct Reasoning. The observed association between training and higher performance reviews is confounded by the fact that training is assigned reactively to those with poor outcomes. This reverse causality means the claim that assigning training will generally improve reviews is invalid.

cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough detail about the intervention, such as the number of users, frequency of use, or changes in workload. Without this critical information, we cannot determine whether using the app causally affects the sense of organization. The claim cannot be verified as stated.

cases.scenario: A company evaluates the productivity of employees who received a special training program. Only those who showed significant improvement after the training are included in the analysis. The company wonders what would have happened if these selected employees had not participated in the training.
cases.claim: Had these employees not received the training, their productivity would not have improved as much.

Z.name: being selected for analysis based on improvement

cases.wise_refusal: This is classic selection bias: by only looking at those who improved, you can't tell what would have happened without the training. The observed improvement may reflect the selection process, not the true effect.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis only includes employees who improved after the training, conditioning on a selected subset. Correct Reasoning. This selection distorts the observed relationship between training and improvement, because only those who improved are considered, regardless of what would have happened without the training. The counterfactual claim is invalid: the selection process creates a spurious association.

cases.scenario: A company wants to reduce employee stress and considers implementing flexible work hours. They collect survey data on stress levels from employees but do not specify whether the flexible hours policy was actually introduced or which employees received it. No details are given about timing or the specific intervention.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their stress levels will decrease.
cases.wise_refusal: We cannot say for sure if assigning flexible work hours will reduce employee stress because the scenario does not specify whether the policy was actually put in place or who received it.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not clarify whether flexible work hours were actually implemented or which employees received the intervention. Without knowing if the action was taken, or having information about timing and assignment, we cannot determine the effect of flexible work hours on stress. The claim cannot be verified from the available information.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to take a 15-minute walk outside during their lunch break every day for two weeks, while another group continues with their usual indoor lunch routine. At the end of the two weeks, both groups complete a standardized survey measuring afternoon energy levels.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to take a daily 15-minute walk outside during lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase compared to those who do not.

X.name: taking a daily 15-minute walk outside during lunch

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario uses random assignment, ensuring that any observed difference in afternoon energy levels can be attributed to the walking intervention.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of the intervention, which eliminates confounding and allows for a valid causal inference at Pearl L2. The comparison between groups directly supports the claim that the intervention increases afternoon energy levels. No causal trap or missing information is present.

cases.scenario: A survey at a local gym found that people who attend group fitness classes tend to report higher levels of motivation to exercise compared to those who work out alone. The data was collected from gym members over the past month and included responses about their workout habits and motivation levels.
cases.claim: Attending group fitness classes is associated with higher motivation to exercise among gym members.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario directly describes an observed association between group class attendance and motivation. No further assumptions are needed at the association level.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes an observed association between attending group fitness classes and higher motivation to exercise, based on survey data. At the L1 (Association) level, this is sufficient to support the claim as stated, since no causal or statistical assumption is violated. The claim does not imply causation, only association, which matches the data provided.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is considering switching from regular office chairs to standing desks to improve their health. The company offers standing desks to anyone who requests one, but no information is provided about how many people actually use them or for how long each day. There are no details about other health-related behaviors or baseline health status.
cases.claim: If we assign standing desks to employees, their overall health will improve.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that simply assigning standing desks will lead to better health, because we don't know how they're used or the employees' starting health. More details are needed before making a causal claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify whether employees actually use the standing desks, how consistently they use them, or what their health status is before the intervention. Without this critical information, we cannot determine if assigning standing desks will causally improve overall health.

cases.scenario: A company reviews only the employees who received performance awards at the end of the year. Among these award recipients, those who worked overtime most frequently tended to have the highest project completion rates. The company wonders what would have happened if these award recipients had not worked overtime as often.
cases.claim: Had the award-winning employees not worked overtime as frequently, their project completion rates would have been much lower.
cases.wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: because only award recipients are included, the link between overtime and completion may be distorted. The claim can't be trusted without considering how selection affects the observed association.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By analyzing only employees who received performance awards, the scenario conditions on a selected group whose inclusion may depend on both overtime and completion rates. Correct Reasoning. This selection can induce or exaggerate an association between overtime and completion rates that does not reflect the true causal effect. The claim incorrectly assumes that the observed relationship among awardees would generalize to all employees or to the same group under different overtime patterns.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers starts a new habit of taking a short walk together during their lunch break. Some coworkers participate, while others do not. The company records show that some employees report feeling more energized in the afternoon, but it is unclear how long each person has been participating in the walks or what other activities they do during lunch.
cases.claim: If we assign coworkers to take a short walk during lunch, they will feel more energized in the afternoon.

X.name: taking a short walk during lunch

Y.name: feeling more energized in the afternoon

cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that taking a walk during lunch leads to feeling more energized in the afternoon because we lack important details about participation and other possible influences.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how long or consistently each coworker has been participating in the walks, nor does it clarify what other lunch activities may affect energy levels. Without this critical information, we cannot confidently determine whether taking a walk causes increased afternoon energy.

cases.scenario: A survey was conducted among office workers to determine how frequently they drink coffee and how often they report feeling alert during the workday. The data shows that workers who drink coffee more regularly tend to report higher levels of alertness compared to those who drink coffee less often.
cases.claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee is associated with feeling more alert during the workday.
cases.wise_refusal: The claim holds because the scenario directly reports an observed association between coffee drinking and alertness among office workers, without requiring any further assumptions.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes an observed association between coffee drinking frequency and reported alertness among office workers. There is no mention of confounding variables or selection bias, and the claim is strictly correlational, matching the Pearl L1 level. Therefore, the claim is supported by the scenario as stated.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is trying to improve their productivity at the office. Some of them start using noise-cancelling headphones during work hours, while others do not. However, there is no information about whether their job roles, tasks, or baseline productivity levels are similar.
cases.claim: If we assign coworkers to use noise-cancelling headphones at work, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that using noise-cancelling headphones will boost productivity because we don't know if the coworkers' jobs or starting productivity levels are comparable. More details are needed to judge this claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether assigning coworkers to use noise-cancelling headphones will increase productivity. Key details are missing, such as whether the coworkers have similar job roles, work environments, or baseline productivity. Without this information, we cannot confidently evaluate the causal effect of the intervention.

cases.scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to use a new productivity app (X) increases their monthly completed tasks (Y). In their analysis, they adjust for the number of app features used (which only becomes relevant after the app is assigned).
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use the new productivity app, their monthly completed tasks will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Be careful not to adjust for variables that happen after the intervention—like app feature use—since this can hide the actual effect of the app assignment.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The number of app features used is a mediator: it occurs after the assignment and is affected by it. Correct Reasoning. Adjusting for this mediator blocks part of the causal pathway from app assignment to task completion, distorting the estimated effect. Wise Refusal. 'Adjusting for a post-treatment variable like app feature use will underestimate the true impact of assigning the app, because it removes part of the effect you want to measure.'

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is considering switching from regular chairs to standing desks in their office. Some employees have already made the change, while others continue to use their usual chairs. However, there is no information about how long each person has been using the standing desk or what other changes they may have made to their work routines.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks instead of regular chairs, their energy levels during the workday will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether switching to standing desks will increase energy levels because we don't know how long employees have used them or if other changes occurred at the same time. More details are needed before making a causal claim.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how long employees have been using standing desks or whether other factors have changed alongside the desk switch. Without knowing the duration of exposure or controlling for other possible influences, we cannot confidently determine the effect of standing desks on energy levels.

cases.scenario: A company implemented a new flexible work schedule policy. After the policy change, employees reported higher job satisfaction, and as a result, the company saw a decrease in staff turnover. An analyst compares turnover rates and claims to have adjusted for job satisfaction when estimating the effect of the policy.
cases.claim: Had the flexible work schedule policy not been implemented, staff turnover would not have decreased, after controlling for job satisfaction.

X.name: implementation of flexible work schedule policy

cases.wise_refusal: Controlling for job satisfaction removes part of the policy's effect on turnover. To estimate the total effect, do not adjust for variables that lie on the causal path from the policy to turnover.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Job satisfaction is a mediator: it is affected by the policy and in turn affects staff turnover. Correct Reasoning. By adjusting for job satisfaction, the analysis blocks the pathway through which the policy affects turnover, underestimating the total effect. Wise Refusal. 'Controlling for a mediator (job satisfaction) breaks the causal chain from policy to turnover, so the claim about the policy's effect is invalid.'

cases.scenario: A manager introduces a new incentive program at work to boost employee productivity. Employees who meet certain targets receive bonuses, and their productivity is measured monthly. After a few months, the manager notices that productivity initially rises, but then employees start setting easier targets to ensure they receive bonuses, leading to a decline in overall productivity.
cases.claim: If we implement a bonus incentive program for employees, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: Beware of feedback effects: employees may adapt to the incentive structure in ways that reduce its effectiveness over time, so the intervention may not reliably increase productivity.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The intervention (bonus program) changes employee behavior, but employees adapt by setting easier targets, creating a feedback loop. Correct Reasoning. The initial boost in productivity is undermined by employees' strategic response, which reduces the intended effect of the intervention over time. Wise Refusal. "This is a classic feedback trap: the policy changes behavior in a way that eventually cancels out its intended effect, so the claim does not hold as stated."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is considering switching from regular chairs to standing desks in their office. Some employees have tried standing desks before, but not everyone has used them. The company is thinking about making standing desks available to all, but there is no information about how long people would use them or whether any other changes would be made to their work environment.
cases.claim: If we assign all employees to use standing desks, their overall productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: We can't be sure that providing standing desks will boost productivity because key details like duration of use and measurement methods are missing. More information is needed before drawing a conclusion.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how productivity is measured, how long employees would use standing desks, or whether other factors in the work environment might change alongside the intervention. Without this critical information, it is not possible to determine whether assigning standing desks would actually increase productivity.

cases.scenario: A company introduced flexible work hours to improve employee satisfaction. Afterward, they noticed that employees who used the new schedule reported higher job satisfaction, but only among those who also attended more team-building events (which were easier to attend with flexible hours). An analyst compares current satisfaction with a hypothetical where flexible hours had not been introduced, but holds the number of team-building events attended constant.
cases.claim: If flexible work hours had not been introduced, employees would not have experienced higher job satisfaction, holding team-building event attendance fixed.
cases.wise_refusal: Fixing a mediator like event attendance blocks part of the effect you want to measure. To assess the true impact of flexible hours, you can't hold constant variables that are affected by them.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Team-building event attendance is a mediator: flexible hours make it easier to attend, which in turn boosts satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. Holding the mediator fixed blocks the indirect effect of flexible hours on satisfaction, underestimating the true causal effect. Wise Refusal. 'By fixing team-building attendance, you ignore part of how flexible hours improve satisfaction. This breaks the causal interpretation.'

cases.scenario: A manager at a tech company notices that when she assigns more challenging tasks to her team, their productivity initially increases. Observing this, she decides to continuously increase the difficulty of assignments, expecting productivity to keep rising. However, as tasks become harder, team members start feeling overwhelmed and their motivation drops, leading to a decline in overall productivity over time.
cases.claim: If we assign more challenging tasks to the team, their productivity will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: This pattern reflects a feedback loop: raising the difficulty may help short-term, but if you keep pushing, people can burn out and productivity can drop. The effect isn’t just one-way—it depends on how the system responds over time.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The manager’s intervention changes the team’s behavior, but the outcome (productivity) also affects future actions: as productivity initially rises, the manager increases task difficulty further, which eventually leads to negative feedback—overwhelm and declining motivation. Correct Reasoning. This feedback loop means the causal effect is not stable; increasing challenge can backfire as the system adapts, violating the simple intervention claim. Wise Refusal. "Be careful with feedback loops: increasing challenge may boost productivity at first, but pushing too far can trigger burnout and reduce performance overall."

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers regularly eat lunch together at the office cafeteria. Some days, the cafeteria menu includes a vegetarian option, but other days it does not. There is no information on how often the vegetarian option is available or how coworkers choose their meals.
cases.claim: If we assign coworkers to eat the vegetarian option at lunch, their afternoon energy levels will increase.

X.name: eating the vegetarian option at lunch

cases.wise_refusal: We cannot determine if assigning coworkers to eat the vegetarian option will increase their afternoon energy levels because the scenario lacks key details about how meals are chosen and what other factors might influence energy.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario does not specify how the vegetarian option is assigned or whether other factors, such as individual dietary preferences or the nutritional content of meals, are considered. Without details on assignment or control for confounding variables, it is unclear if eating the vegetarian option causally affects afternoon energy levels.

cases.scenario: A group of employees who regularly bike to work were observed to have lower stress levels than those who do not. Suppose that, in reality, people who live closer to the office are both more likely to bike and tend to have less stressful commutes due to shorter travel times.
cases.claim: Had the employees not biked to work, their stress levels would have been just as low.
cases.wise_refusal: This is a classic confounding problem: living near the office can cause both more biking and less stress. The claim overlooks that proximity, not biking, may be the real reason for lower stress.
cases.label: NO
cases.gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Living close to the office (Z) influences both the likelihood of biking to work (X) and lower stress levels (Y). Correct Reasoning. The observed association between biking and stress may be confounded by proximity to the office; those who live closer are both more likely to bike and to experience less stress, regardless of biking. Thus, the counterfactual claim ignores this confounder.

cases.scenario: A group of coworkers is considering switching from regular chairs to standing desks in their office. Some employees have already made the switch, while others continue to use traditional chairs. However, the scenario does not mention how long each person has been using the standing desk or whether any other changes were made to their work environment.
cases.claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks instead of regular chairs, their overall energy levels during the workday will increase.
cases.wise_refusal: It's unclear whether assigning standing desks will actually increase energy levels, since we don't know how long people have been using them or if other factors might be influencing their energy. More details are needed to draw a reliable conclusion.
cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario lacks critical information such as the duration of standing desk use, possible differences in other workplace factors, and whether energy levels were measured before and after the intervention. Without these details, we cannot confidently determine the causal effect of standing desks on energy levels.

cases.scenario: A group of office workers are randomly assigned to use standing desks for two months, while another group continues using traditional sitting desks. At the end of the period, researchers measure the average number of steps taken per day by both groups, finding that the standing desk group consistently takes more steps during work hours.
cases.claim: If we assign office workers to use standing desks, they will increase their daily number of steps during work hours.

Y.name: daily number of steps during work hours

cases.wise_refusal: The claim is valid because the scenario involves a randomized intervention and clear measurement of the outcome, so we can confidently attribute the increase in steps to the use of standing desks.
cases.label: YES
cases.gold_rationale: The scenario describes a randomized assignment of workers to standing desks, which controls for confounding variables. The outcome, daily steps, is measured objectively, and the comparison between groups directly supports the causal effect of standing desk use on increasing steps. No causal assumptions are violated, and the claim is supported as stated.
